questions.text: Where does fluid accumulate in central serous retinopathy?

choices.text: Between the Bruch membrane and retinal pigment epithelium
Between the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer

questions.solution:
Fluid accumulation in central serous retinopathy (CSR) is in the subretinal space due to abnormal permeability of the choriocapillaris.

The image depicts optical coherence tomography showing fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment.

questions.text: In 1884, a paper on the local anaesthetic action of cocaine in ophthalmic surgery was published and was lauded by ophthalmologists all over the world. Who proposed it?
questions.solution:
Cocaine was the first topical anaesthetic and was discovered by Carl Koller in 1884.

He first introduced cocaine as a topical anaesthetic for ophthalmologic surgery of the cornea. Thereafter, cocaine was used for intradermal infiltration and nerve blocks by William Halsted.

Joseph Priestley: First synthesized nitrous oxide.

Humphrey Davy: Experimented with nitrous oxide and named it laughing gas.

William Morton: Introduced ether anaesthesia.

Dr Carl Koller (1857-1944) was a medical student in Vienna when he befriended a young Sigmund Freud (1856-1939). Experimenting on themselves, they studied a new wonder drug named cocaine. Dr Koller was nicknamed "Coca Koller" by Freud, as discovered in one of the many letters they shared.

questions.text: Which of the following is a chain-breaking antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Vitamin E is a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Antioxidants are used to control and reduce lipid peroxidation during which reactive oxygen species (ROS) are formed. Antioxidants thus fall into two classes:

  • Preventive: These reduce the rate of chain initiation of lipid peroxidation.
  • Chain-breaking: These interfere with the chain propagation phase of lipid peroxidation.

Related Pearl: Types of Antioxidants

Preventive Antioxidants

Chain-breaking Antioxidants
  • Catalase
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Chelator of metal Ions-Ceruloplasmin & Transferrin
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Urate
  • Vitamin E
  • Polyphenols

questions.text: In a bacterial growth curve, the period in which maximum cell size is obtained is _____
questions.solution:
The bacterial growth curve is characterized by an initial lag phase, followed by log phase or exponential growth phase, then reaching a stationary phase followed by phase of decline.

  1. Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence by the end of lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained
  2. Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time
  3. Stationary phase: The viable count remains stationary as an equilibrium exists between the dying and the newly formed cells.
  4. Phase of decline: Cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death.

questions.text: Matching is done for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Matching helps only in removing the known confounding factors.

Matching is the process by which controls are selected in a way that they are similar to cases in certain pertinent variables (e.g., age) that are known to influence the outcome of the disease. If not adequately matched for comparability, these variables could confound the results.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the casualty after he was found lying near a ditch. He had a laceration over his scalp. His GCS on arrival was 13 and after a few minutes, it dropped to 10. A plain CT scan was done and given below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan showing a concavo-convex shaped hematoma on the left side with a midline shift to the right is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses.

The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands.

Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text:
A 15-year old boy presents with persistent vomiting for one day. Laboratory investigations reveal the following. What is the best sequence of management?

Random blood glucose: 400 mg/dl

Serum sodium: 133 mEq/L

Serum potassium: 3 mEq/L

Urine ketone bodies: 4+

choices.text: Start IV fluids, administer IV regular insulin, and then correct hypokalemia
Start IV fluids, administer subcutaneous bolus of insulin and correct hypokalemia concurrently
Start IV fluids and correct hypokalemia first, then administer IV regular insulin
Administer IV regular insulin with KCl first , then start IV fluids once the K+ level is corrected

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). On confirming the diagnosis, IV fluids must be started. If the initial serum potassium < 3.3 meq/L, insulin should be administered only after the correction of hypokalemia.

This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia by the following mechanisms:

  • Insulin causes the shift of K+ ions into cells
  • Resolution of the acidosis also promotes K+ entry into cells
  • Urinary loss of K+ salts of organic acids

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporter in the myocytes is under the influence of insulin?
questions.solution:
GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter in the myocytes under the influence of insulin.

Glucose transport in our body mainly occurs through sodium-independent glucose transporters, which include GLUT transporters and to a small extent through sodium-dependent glucose transporters, which include SGLT-1 and SGLT-2. Insulin induces the movement of intracellular GLUT 4 molecules to the cell surface and thus increases glucose uptake. In type 2 diabetes mellitus, membrane GLUT 4 is reduced, leading to insulin resistance in muscle and fat cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of the eye?

choices.text: The macula is fully developed at birth.
The cornea attains normal diameter by 2 years.
Full visual acuity is attained by 6 years of age.

questions.solution:
The macula is fully developed by 4–6 months of age. Apart from the macula, the rest of the retina is fully developed at birth.

Postnatal Development of Eye: 

  • 3 Months - Binocular single vision develops.
  • 4-6 Months - Macula fully develops. Fusional reflexes, stereopsis, and accommodation become well developed
  • 6 Months - Fixation, which had started developing in the first month is now complete
  • 2 Years - Cornea develops to the normal adult diameter
  • 6 Years - Visual acuity fully develops and reaches 6/6
  • The lens, however, continues to grow throughout the life

Related Pearl: Visual development

Age
Visual development
At birth
Fixation at light held 8–10 inches away - momentarily
6–8 weeks
Fixation at light and moving objects - more steadily
3 months
Follows moving objects
5–6 months
Depth perception, color vision, and eye–body coordination

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with recurrent headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Her blood pressure was found to be 170/110 mm Hg. Further testing revealed elevated urinary metanephrines. An MRI was negative. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The diagnosis can be confirmed by gallium-68 somatostatin receptor DOTATOC PET scan.

Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy shows increased activity in paragangliomas and is a useful technique for identifying extra-adrenal phaeochromocytomas. The compounds often used in molecular imaging with PET include 68Ga-DOTATOC, 68Ga-DOTATATE, and 68Ga-DOTANOC. They bind to somatostatin receptors with varying affinity for different receptors.

This investigation is useful in the diagnosis of new lesions in patients with or suspected neuroendocrine tumors. 

Other options: 

Option A: C11 methionine PET is a radiolabelled amino acid, and tumour uptake reflects cellular proliferation and microvessel density. It is used in the grading of brain tumors, differential diagnosis and identifying recurrence. 

Option B: 18F-NaF PET uptake reflects blood flow and bone remodelling. It is used for imaging bone pathology by detecting primary and secondary bone tumours. 

Option D: 99mTc pertechnetate is useful for thyroid nodules, and ectopic gastric mucosa.

Note: The investigation of choice for adrenal phaeochromocytoma is contrast-enhanced MRI.

questions.text: Identify the artery of epistaxis in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked 3 is the sphenopalatine artery which is also known as the artery of epistaxis.

It is called the artery of epistaxis because the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is derived from it. It is also the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

1 - Anterior ethmoidal artery

2 - Posterior ethmoidal artery

4 - Greater palatine artery

questions.text: The use of which of the following drugs is unlikely to trigger an anaphylaxis reaction in a patient?
questions.solution:
The use of fentanyl is unlikely to cause an anaphylactic reaction. True allergic reactions to opioids like fentanyl are very rare. 

The most common cause of anaphylactic reactions during anesthesia is antibiotics (especially penicillin and cephalosporin), followed by neuromuscular blockers (rocuronium).

Amino ester local anesthetics (procaine) exhibit allergic reactions due to the metabolite PABA. Sulfa drugs like sulfonamide antibiotics, furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, and captopril also exhibit allergy in surgical patients.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolytes is measured in Gettler’s test?
questions.solution:
Gettler's test measures the chloride content of left and right side of the heart.

A difference of 25 mg% in chloride concentrations between the two sides of the heart is an indication of death due to drowning. This test was used to identify the cause of drowning. 

  • Freshwater drowning - chloride content of left heart is lower than that of the right heart
  • Saltwater drowning - chloride content of right heart is lower than that of the left heart

Gettler's claims have been refuted and the test is no longer accepted.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria shows Kanagawa phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It refers to hemolysis occuring when the bacteria are inoculated on Wagatsuma agar.

Pathogenic strains of V. parahaemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This phenomenon occurs due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: The forearm of a patient admitted to the psychiatric ward is shown in the image. Which of the following is true about the healed injury?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hypertrophic scars which have developed on possible sites of self-inflicted cuts. Type 3 collagen fibers are arranged parallelly in hypertrophic scars. This is in contrast to a keloid where the collagen fibers are more and randomly arranged. 

Hypertrophic scars rise above the skin level but stay within the confines of the original wound and often regress over time. They have no racial or genetic predilection. 

Difference between keloid and hypertrophic scar:

Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial Maybe familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on extensor surface) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus, respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

questions.text: A village has a population of 30,000 people. 500 of them contracted a disease X, out of which 75 died. What is the case fatality rate?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is given by the formula:

The total number of cases of disease X= 500

The total number of deaths= 75

Hence the case fatality rate= 75/500 x 100 = 15%

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Somatization?

choices.text: Acute onset and less long lasting

questions.solution:
Symptoms in somatisation disorders are chronic in nature.

Somatization Disorder:

  • Refers to the existence of multiple somatic symptoms that are present for a long duration of time which is basically due to psychological problems manifesting as somatic problems.
  • All organic causes must be ruled out before making the diagnosis of somatoform disorder.

Diagnostic criteria for somatic symptom disorder(DSM-V)

One or more somatic symptoms that cause distress or significantly disrupt daily life

Excessive thoughts or behaviours related to the somatic symptoms, as demonstrated by the following:

Unwarranted and persistent thoughts about the seriousness of the condition

Persistent anxiety about health or symptoms

Too much time and energy dedicated to these symptoms

Symptoms persist for ≥6 months( not all symptoms may be present simultaneously)

According to DSM-IV each of the below has to be present for the diagnosis of somatization disorder(Briquet’s syndrome):

4 pain symptoms –headache, backache, joint pain etc

2 gastrointestinal symptoms- nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea

1 sexual symptoms –impotence, erectile dysfunction, menstrual disturbances

1 pseudo neurological symptom- paraesthesia, glove and stocking anaesthesia

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustained a spinal cord injury as a result of a road traffic accident. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. All of the following findings can be seen in the patient except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the presence of hypotension associated with the spinal cord injury is suggestive of neurogenic shock. It is associated with bradycardia and not tachycardia.

Neurogenic shock refers to reduced tissue perfusion due to loss of vasomotor tone to peripheral arterial beds.

Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic regulation of peripheral vascular tone. Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in increased vascular capacitance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output.

The classic description of neurogenic shock consists of:

  • Hypotension associated with bradycardia (absence of reflexive tachycardia due to disrupted sympathetic discharge)
  • Warm extremities (due to loss of peripheral vasoconstriction)
  • Motor and sensory deficits indicative of a spinal cord injury
  • Radiographic evidence of a vertebral column fracture

questions.text: A primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of the expulsion of grape-like vesicles PV for the past day. A diagnosis of molar pregnancy was made on USG examination. Incidentally, the following adnexal lesion was also noted. What is the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. These cysts are usually seen in patients with complete molar pregnancies. They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple pregnancies.

Theca lutein cysts result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of β hCG. The cystic fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin, estrogen, and progesterone.

questions.text: You are counseling a patient with gastroesophageal reflux disease about the need for long-term therapy with proton-pump inhibitors. All of the following are complications of this therapy, except:
questions.solution:
Long-term PPI therapy is not associated with hypogastrinemia but is associated with hypergastrinemia. This hypergastrinemia contributes to rebound gastric acid hypersecretion if PPI therapy is discontinued.

Chronic PPI therapy is associated with: 

  • Decreased vitamin B12 absorption
  • Increased susceptibility to infections- hospital-acquired pneumonia, pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Reduced calcium absorption increases the risk of fractures

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of the muscle inserted to the area marked below?
questions.solution:
The marked area on the mandible is the pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side to side movement of the jaw.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, the capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and the articular disc.

questions.text: Serum concentrations of which of the following decrease during inflammation?
questions.solution:
During inflammation, there are reduced levels of albumin.

This occurs in order to allow an increase in the liver's capacity to synthesize acute phase reactants. Hence, albumin is called a negative phase reactant.

Negative acute-phase proteins concentration decreases during inflammation. These are:

  • Albumin
  • Transferrin
  • Retinol-binding protein
  • Antithrombin
  • Transcortin
  • Alpha 2-HS glycoprotein
  • Alpha-fetoprotein
  • Thyroxin-binding protein
  • Insulin-like growth factor 1
  • Factor 12

Acute-phase proteins are plasma proteins synthesized by the liver in response to inflammation. These include C-reactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A (SAA) protein. The synthesis of these molecules in hepatocytes is stimulated by cytokines. IL-6 stimulates the synthesis of CRP and fibrinogen and IL-1 or TNF for SAA.

Related Pearl: Acute phase reactants and their functions

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl with a history of easy bruising was referred for further evaluation. Her previous lab reports showed that platelet count and morphology were normal. Platelet aggregations tests are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
Agonist used Aggregation
ADP Absent
Epinephrine Absent
Collagen Absent
Ristocetin Normal
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to each other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage.

Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include:

  • Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa
  • Type 2: Reduced surface expression of GPIIb-IIIa/ Essentialis athrombia - clot retraction is normal
  • Type 3: Dysfunction of GPIIb-IIIa

Laboratory features of Glanzmann thrombasthenia:

  • Normal platelet count and morphology
  • Platelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin, but not to other agonists (such as ADP, thrombin, collagen or epinephrine)
  • Clot retraction is absent

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for angina, presents to you with erectile dysfunction. You decide against prescribing sildenafil because the patient is being treated with _____
questions.solution:
The patient would be on nitrates for angina and thus should not be prescribed sildenafil as sildenafil causes dangerous potentiation of nitrate action resulting in severe hypotension.

The combination of the two drugs has a synergistic action on the intracellular cGMP levels that can result in uninhibited vasodilation and a precipitous fall in blood pressure. Hence, the use of sildenafil is a contraindication when on nitrates.

questions.text: A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress soon after birth. On examination, the child has frothing of saliva and the resident suspects tracheoesophageal fistula. What is the most common type of fistula likely to be present in this child?
questions.solution:
Type C is the commonest variety of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). 

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. The proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. 

Drooling of saliva, inability to pass a nasogastric tube and history of polyhydramnios suggest a diagnosis of oesophagal atresia with or without TEF. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the oesophagal pouch as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: Which of the following biomarkers is preferred for diagnosing reinfarction in a patient post-NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
Troponin(serial) is the preferred biomarker for diagnosing reinfarction.

Serial troponin levels are used to detect reinfarction, an acute MI that occurs within 28 days of an incident or recurrent MI. 

In case of suspected reinfarction, an immediate measurement of cardiac troponin followed by a second sample after 3-6 hours. ≥20 percent rise in the second sample suggests reinfarction.


Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

This is AIIMS pattern question. Detailed and thorough knowledge on cardiac cycle, pressures and volumes is a must for any entrance exam as it a frequently tested topic.

questions.text: What does the biochemical oxygen demand of sewage indicate?
questions.solution:
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) indicates the organic content of sewage.

It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage for aerobic destruction by living microorganisms.

If wastewater contains toxic substances, the organic load is measured by the chemical oxygen demand.

Related Pearl: Strength of Sewage

The strength of sewage is expressed by the following.

  • Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD):
    • It is the standard test which is an indicator of the organic content of sewage
    • It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage during a specified period (generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20 deg.C) for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living microorganisms.
    • A high BOD (300 mg/l) indicates a high content of easily degradable, organic material while a low BOD (100mg/l) indicates the presence of content that is not easily degradable, low volume of organic matter or measurement problems.
  • Chemical oxygen demand (COD):
    • This test measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidizer
    • This is mostly used when sewage contains toxic wastes
  • Suspended solids:
    • The amount of suspended solids in sewage may vary from 100 to 500 ppm (mg/litre)
    • If the level of suspended solids is 100 ppm, then sewage is weak and if it is more than 500 ppm, sewage is strong.

questions.text:
Match the following marked structures to the correct layers of the epidermis.
  1. Stratum granulosum
  2. Stratum corneum
  3. Stratum spinosum
  4. Stratum basale
questions.solution:
The image shows the histological section of the epidermis. The structures marked are respectively:

  1.  Stratum corneum
  2.  Stratum granulosum
  3.  Stratum spinosum
  4.  Stratum basale

The above 4 layers are present in the thin hairy skin. 

The thick glabrous skin over the palms and the soles alone contains a clear homogenous 5th layer between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum, called the stratum lucidum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the potency and efficacy of a drug is not true?

choices.text: In a clinical setup, efficacy is more important than potency
In the log dose response curve, the height of the curve corresponds with efficacy
ED50 of the drug corresponds to the efficacy
Drugs that produce a similar pharmacological effect can have different levels of efficacy

questions.solution:
ED50 is a measure of the drug potency, not efficacy.

Potency refers to the amount of the drug required to produce a certain response. The x coordinates (dose axis) on the log dose-response curve (DRC) of a drug represent the potency of the drug. A right shift in the DRC indicates a lower potency and vice versa.

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The efficacy of a drug is a more decisive factor in the choice of a drug in the clinical setting
  • The more the curve shifts towards the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, Drug A is more potent. The potency is  Drug A > Drug B > Drug C > Drug D.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • It is mainly a factor in choosing the dose of a drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, efficacy is Drug A >B > C > D.

questions.text: The type of epithelium as shown in the image below is present in ______.
questions.solution:
The type of epithelium shown in the image is the transitional epithelium and it is present in the urinary bladder.

Transitional epithelium is a specialized epithelium lining most of the urinary tract, hence it is also called the urothelium. The deepest layer consists of columnar or cuboidal cells, and the middle layer consists of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells. The surface layer consists of large, polypoid, dome-shaped, or umbrella-shaped cells. As the epithelium gets stretched to accommodate urine, the surface cells become flattened. The cells are called transitional due to this apparent change (transition) from stratified cuboidal epithelium in a relaxed state to stratified squamous epithelium when it is stretched.

They are present in:

  • Collecting ducts
  • Renal pelvis and calyces
  • Ureter
  • Urinary bladder
  • Pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of urethra

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency department after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

 In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

questions.text: A known case of seizure disorder has been on long-term phenytoin therapy. Which of the following statements about this drug would be incorrect?

choices.text: Metabolism follows only zero order kinetics
Metabolized extensively by the CYP enzymes in the liver

questions.solution:
Phenytoin follows first-order kinetics at lower concentrations and as the concentration increases, the elimination changes to zero-order kinetics. The rate of elimination of phenytoin varies with the serum concentration.

As the blood levels rise, the maximal capacity of the liver to metabolize phenytoin is reached. Thus even a small increase in the dosage can result in disproportionally high plasma levels. Therefore, it requires therapeutic drug monitoring. 

About 90% of phenytoin is bound to plasma proteins, mainly albumin. Phenytoin is metabolized by the CYP enzymes in the liver.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: What are the walls of the CT scanner rooms coated with?
questions.solution:
Lead is the most common agent used in modern construction because of it's ability to provide radiation shielding. Lead can effectively attenuate certain kinds of radiation because of its high density and atomic number.

Lead aprons are used to safeguard from scattered radiation. Their thickness is 0.5 mm (0.25 – 0.5 mm).

questions.text: A first-year pathology resident prepares the following smear from a patient's blood sample. Which of the following is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The small, dense RBCs with absent central pallor seen in the given peripheral smear are called spherocytes. They appear due to decreased membrane surface area and are seen in the following conditions:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Clostridial sepsis
  • Snake bites

questions.text: A 61-year-old man, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus, presents with headache and eye pain. He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Examination showed a laminar dot sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with headache and eye pain along with the finding of a laminar dot sign is suggestive of glaucoma.

The laminar dot sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc. This occurs because the pores in the lamina cribrosa are slit-shaped and are visible up to the margin of the disc.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early glaucomatous changes:

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup - 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes:

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayonetting sign - Sharp angulation of vessel at the margin of the excavated cup
  • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to:
questions.solution:
The given egg belongs to whipworm or Trichuris trichiura.

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

Whipworms live in the large intestine and whipworm eggs are passed in the feces of infected persons. The eggs develop in the soil in 3-4 weeks and become infective to man. When these embryonated eggs containing infective larvae contaminate food or water, they can cause infections in humans. 

 

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Among the Purkinje images in the eye, which image is inverted?
questions.solution: Image 4, which is formed on the posterior surface of the lens, is inverted.

questions.text: An elderly patient who presented with abdominal discomfort and weight loss was diagnosed with type I gastric cancer according to Lauren’s classification. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Type I gastric cancer is associated with hematogenous spread. 

Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer pathology as either type I (intestinal) or type II (diffuse), based on differences in etiology, epidemiology, and pathology. Intestinal type of gastric cancer shows hematogenous spread, whereas diffuse-type shows transmural and lymphatic spread.

Related Pearl: Lauren Classification System of gastric carcinoma

Environmental

Gastric atrophy, intestinal metaplasia

  Blood type A
Men > women Women > Men
Increasing incidence with age Younger age group
Gland formation Poorly differentiated, signet ring cells 
Hematogenous spread Transmural, lymphatic spread

Microsatellite instability

APC gene mutations

p53, p16 inactivation p53, p16 inactivation

questions.text: A patient underwent an aortic valve replacement surgery through the femoral artery. Post-operatively, he complaints of groin pain radiating down the anteromedial thigh. Which of the following is true regarding the nerve injured?

choices.text: It lies medial to the femoral artery
It is not a content of the femoral sheath
The nerve injured is the sciatic nerve
It arises from the anterior cords of the lumbar plexus

questions.solution:
The nerve injured is the femoral nerve. Femoral nerve is not a content of the femoral sheath. 

Femoral sheath forms a fascial compartment which is further divided into 3 compartments by the intervening septae:

  • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains 
    • Lymphatic vessels
    • Areolar tissue
    • Lymph node of cloquet

The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.

Option A - Femoral nerve lies lateral to the femoral artery

Option C - Sciatic nerve injury may occur after misplaced intramuscular injection in the gluteal region. It leads to loss of sensation at the outer side of ankle and heel and foot drop.

questions.solution:
The given logo represents cytotoxic waste. 

Cytotoxic drugs and the items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs are disposed in yellow bags. They are treated by incineration, plasma pyrolysis, or encapsulation.

questions.text: A 75-year old man came with complaints of a painless nodule on the left palm for the past 4 weeks. He gave a history of sustaining a thorn prick injury to the palm 5 weeks ago. On examination, the lesion appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing an exophytic nodule with central keratinous debris is suggestive of keratoacanthoma.

Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma. It presents clinically as a proliferating dome-shaped keratin-filled crater. Patients usually give a prior history of minor trauma. Treatment of choice is an excisional procedure with 4 mm margins.

Option A: Actinic keratoses consist of hyperkeratotic erythematous papules and patches on the sun-exposed skin. They arise in middle-aged to older adults and have some potential for malignant transformation.

Option B: Bowen's disease appears histologically as SCC in situ. It initially presents with a red­dened area that progresses to thickened plaques and may vary from small lesions (<1 cm) to large areas. When it is confined to the glans penis or vulva, Bowen disease is sometimes referred to as Erythroplasia of Queyrat.

Option D: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T cell lymphoma, and plaque-stage lesions are seen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with thunderclap headaches and seizures. There is no history of trauma. Non-contrast CT was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a thunderclap headache and seizures with the given CT scan showing hyperdense areas corresponding to blood in the subarachnoid basal cisterns suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

Patients present with a sudden and severe headache referred to as thunderclap headache, which may be associated with vomiting, decreased consciousness, and seizures. Neck stiffness and photophobia may develop after a few hours.

Non-contrast CT scan is the imaging modality of choice if done within 12 hours. It shows an increased density of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. A lumbar puncture should be done if there is a strong suspicion of SAH but negative CT findings. It is ideally done 12 hours later. This allows for red blood cell lysis to occur and bilirubin to be detected in the CSF.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: The anaerobic gram-positive bacillus showing reverse CAMP test positive is ______
questions.solution:
Reverse CAMP test is used for the identification of Clostridium perfringens.

Reverse CAMP test :
The test is called the reverse CAMP test because CAMP factor produced by Streptococcus agalactiae is used for the detection of Clostridium perfringens from other Clostridium species.

Principle:

  • A CAMP-positive group B Streptococcus is streaked in the center of sheep blood agar, and Clostridium perfringens is streaked perpendicular to it.
  • This is because of alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens interacts with CAMP factor and produce synergistic hemolysis.

questions.text: You are a radiation oncology resident explaining the harmful effects of radiation to a patient. Which of the following is not a deterministic effect of the same?
questions.solution:
Mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: stochastic and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

 

Stochastic effects

 Deterministic effects
Description These are chance effects. The probability of occurrence increases with increasing absorbed dose, but severity does not depend on the amount of absorbed dose. This is called the 'all or none' phenomenon. Increases in severity with increasing absorbed dose in affected individuals.
Threshold level It cannot be set. It can be set.
Examples  Genetic effect, development of cancer Organ atrophy, fibrosis, lens opacification, blood changes, decrease in sperm count, irreversible skin damage,fetal abnormalities

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by plasma cells. Histology also shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes and eosinophils. 

The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies(marked in black arrows)

Rhinoscleroma starts in the nose and extends to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, subglottic larynx, trachea and bronchi. It has 3 stages:

  1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose.
  3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx and larynx. 

Treatment is done by the use of antibiotics streptomycin and tetracycline for 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids to reduce fibrosis. Surgical intervention may be required to restore the airway and correct the nasal deformity. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy are negative. 

Other options:

Option B: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi characterised by multiple polypoidal growths. The biopsy shows several oval or round-shaped sporangia filled with spores bursting through the chitinous walls.

Option C: Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculosis infection characterised by chronic vestibulitis and perforation of the nasal septum. Biopsy shows tuberculous granuloma and caseous necrosis.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangitis is a chronic granulomatous disorder presenting with crusting, granulation and saddle deformity of the nose. Biopsy shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis of the vessels.

questions.text: Which nerve fibers most susceptible to local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Nerve fiber most susceptible to local anesthetic is type B.

The order of sensitivity of nerve fibers to local anesthesia is B > A gamma > A delta > A beta > A alpha.

Factors that increase the sensitivity of nerves :

  • Smaller diameter
  • Unmyelinated nerves are more sensitive
  • Other anatomic and physiological factors

C fiber: The sensitivity of C fibers to local anesthesia is a controversial topic. As C fibers are both unmyelinated and have a smaller diameter, it is expected that they would be more sensitive. But they show an unusual resistance to inhibition by local anesthetics.

Controversial: There is a difference of opinion on this topic among various standard textbooks and authors.

According to Katzung pharmacology 14th Ed. page no. 465,  B=C > A-delta > A gamma > A beta > A alpha

Ganong's Physiology 26th Ed. page no. 92, nerve fiber susceptibility to local anesthetics is in the order C > B > A

Hence, the correct answer would solely depend on the reference book the examiner referred to while making the question.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift?

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
It accounts for major epidemics of influenza
The new antigens formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralise the new variants

questions.solution:
Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure.

Antigenic drift accounts for periodic epidemics, not major epidemics of influenza. This property forms the basis for the development of annual influenza vaccines. The new antigens formed are similar to the previous antigens and antibodies to the predecessor viruses can neutralise the new variants to some extent. 

Antigenic variation is a property of influenza viruses by which it alters the surface antigenic structure (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase) and thus avoids a host immune response. It is of two types - antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

  Antigenic shift Antigenic drift
Antigenic structure Abrupt, drastic change Gradual, sequential change 
Periodicity  10 - 20 years 2 - 3 years   
Epidemiological effect Pandemics and major epidemics  Periodic epidemics and sporadic cases
Genetic cause Large genetic re-assortment Accumulation of point mutations
Antibodies to predecessor strains Do not neutralize the new variant Neutralizes the new variant to varying degrees
Clinical relevance  Animal-origin viruses infecting humans e.g. Swine flu, COVID-19

Annual influenza vaccine development

Common cold - People can get flu more than once

questions.text: In a patient undergoing pulmonary artery catheterisation, which of the following would denote entry into the pulmonary artery?
questions.solution:
Entry into the pulmonary artery is indicated by an increase in diastolic pressure.

Pulmonary artery catheterization involves the use of a Swan-Ganz catheter.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the final structure to drain lymphatics from the stomach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the intestinal lymph trunk is the last structure to drain lymphatics from the stomach. 

The intestinal lymph trunk is a major lymphatic channel in the abdomen. It receives lymphatics from the pre-aortic group of lymph nodes such as coeliac nodes, superior mesenteric nodes, and inferior mesenteric nodes. The intestinal lymph trunk finally drains into the cisterna chyli.

The lymphatic drainage of the stomach can be divided into four zones as shown in the image below.

questions.text:
Which of the following components are included under the modified Kuppuswamy scale for socio-economic status ?
  1. Income of family
  2. Monetary value of material possessions
  3. Education of head of family
  4. Occupation of head of family
  5. Number of family members
questions.solution:
The modified Kuppuswamy scale uses income of the family, education and occupation of head of family.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: Which of the following is the carrier of arachidonic acid from membrane to  5-LOX?
questions.solution:
FLAP (five lipoxygenase activating protein) carries arachidonic acid to 5-LOX.

A membrane associated transfer protein called FLAP carries arachidonic acid to 5-LOX, and is essential forthe synthesis of LTs.

questions.text: The following investigation was performed in a patient with postmenopausal bleeding. Which of the following is false about the same?

choices.text: A condom is placed over the probe

questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates transvaginal ultrasonography. The bladder should be empty and not full, for transvaginal USG (TVS) to allow visualisation of other structures.

A condom is placed on the transducer before the TVS transducer is inserted into the vagina. It provides higher-resolution images compared to transabdominal USG because of the proximity to the pelvic organs. During a transabdominal ultrasound, the bladder should be full to create a good echo window.

Indications of TVS include early pregnancy, LUS in late pregnancy, ectopic, pelvic masses, obese patients, follicular and endometrial studies, doppler examination of pelvic organs and interventional procedures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease presents to the OPD with fever and right upper abdominal pain. A diagnostic laparoscopy was done and the findings are as given below. Which of the following organisms could be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The scenario depicted is Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome which is a rare complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) following infection with Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

It causes liver capsule inflammation leading to the creation of violin-string adhesions which can be seen on laparoscopy. On CT imaging it appears as perihepatic inflammatory stranding and hepatic capsular enhancement.

The major symptom and signs include right upper quadrant pain. It is also associated with minimal pelvic pain, vaginal discharge, or cervical motion tenderness.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
questions.solution:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

 Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
  • Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally.

Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid
  • Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve occurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases
  • Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds.

questions.text: Which gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity?
questions.solution:
PTPN22 gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.

PTPN22, which encodes the protein tyrosine phosphatase, is associated with the following conditions:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Type 1 diabetes

Because these disorders have a fairly high prevalence, PTPN22 is said to be the gene that is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.

Option A: Mutations in FOXP3 cause a systemic autoimmune disease called IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).

Option C: Polymorphisms in the gene encoding for NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease.

Option D: AIRE mutation is associated with the autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

questions.text: Which of the following is a nonstructural gene of HIV?
questions.solution:
The tat gene (trans-activating gene) is a non-structural gene. 

HIV has structural and non-structural genes: 

  • Structural genes- Genes coding for structural protiens:  
    • gag- Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24  
    • env- Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41
    • pol- Codes for enzymes: Polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease
  • Non-structural and regulatory genes:
    • tat- Trans-activating gene
    • nef- Negative factor gene
    • rev- Regulator of virus gene
    • vif- Viral infectivity factor gene
    • vpu- (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2)
    • vpr- Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus
    • LTR- Long terminal repeat sequences

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with Parkinsonism and cerebellar features. MRI showed the finding as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Parkinsonism, cerebellar features, and the 'hot cross bun' sign on MRI suggest multiple system atrophy (MSA).

MSA manifests as a combination of parkinsonian, cerebellar, and autonomic features. Based on predominant clinical features it is further divided into :

  • MSA-P:
    • Predominantly parkinsonian features are seen
    • T2 weighted MRI demonstrates hyperintense putaminal rim
  • MSA-C:
    • Predominantly cerebellar features are seen
    • MRI shows cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

questions.text: The X-Ray shown below can best relate to which of the following options?
questions.solution:
• The X-Ray shows a classic mortar and pestle appearance of the acetabulum where the femoral head is has shifted medially and the Acetabular cavity looks deepened.
  • The stage of apparent shortening is seen with the stage of arthritis, that is, stage 2. If the disease starts healing there will be signs of sclerosis around the hip that can be seen.
  • The Phemister triad of tuberculosis of the hip joint:
    • Peri-articular osteoporosis
    • Peripherally located osseous erosion
    • Gradual diminution of joint space

    This suggests the diagnosis of TB hip joint.

questions.text: In which stage of sleep are sleep spindles and K-complexes observed?
questions.solution:
Sleep spindles and K complexes are observed in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep architecture, stages of sleep and the corresponding EEG pattern of NREM sleep, non-rapid eye movement sleep:

  • Stage 1- wakefulness to sleep, the disappearance of alpha activity, and appearance of theta activity
  • Stage 2- characterized by sleep spindles and k-complexes
  • Stage 3 and stage 4 NREM- slow delta waves are seen

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness, dull aching abdominal pain, and diarrhea. On examination, his face and chest appear flushed. CT scan of the abdomen shows a tumor in the terminal ileum with liver metastasis. An increased levels of 5-HIAA is seen in a 24-hour urinary sample. Which of the following is false regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery should be done as soon as the diagnosis is made.
MRI is the best method for staging of the disease.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carcinoid syndrome caused by a carcinoid tumour. The best method for the staging of a carcinoid tumour is the octreotide scan.

They are neuroendocrine tumours of the gastrointestinal tract. They arise from the enterochromaffin cells. They metastasize early to the regional lymph nodes and the liver.

Abdominal symptoms include:

  • Pain
  • Abdominal distension
  • Lower GI bleeding

Metastasis in these patients can cause increased production of serotonin leading to carcinoid syndrome with features like:

  • Flushing
  • Diarrhoea
  • Bronchospasm
  • Cardiac symptoms because of stenosis and insufficiency of the cardiac valves

The diagnosis is made by an assessment of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumours only if metastases are present.  

Ultrasonography, CT scan, and MRI may show the primary tumour and metastases. The best method for staging carcinoid tumours is by octreotide scan or somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).

Treatment:

  • Somatostatin and its analogues are used in the symptomatic treatment of carcinoid syndrome. 
  • Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of liver metastases.
  • Resection of the primary tumour and mesenteric lymph node metastases is done. 
  • In the presence of liver metastasis - liver resection, transarterial embolization (TAE), chemoembolization (TACE), chemotherapy, and liver transplantation can be done.

Historically, adenocarcinoma of the small intestine had a higher incidence than carcinoid tumours, but this has changed over the past decade.

  • The most common small intestine tumour is carcinoid.
  • The most common site of small intestine carcinoid is the ileum.

Regarding small intestine tumours excluding carcinoid:

  • The most common site of small intestine tumour (excluding carcinoid) is the duodenum.
  • The most common duodenal tumour is adenocarcinoma.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: Acetohydroxamic acid will be prescribed for patients with which of the following types of renal stones?
questions.solution:
Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone.

It is a urease inhibitor. The urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine. This favors the production of struvite stones. Thus, the use of AHA(Acetohydroxamic acid) causes complete, noncompetitive inhibition of urease production, thereby slowing struvite stone growth. Owing to its side-effects, the use of this drug has been restricted in cases of recurrent UTIs, and those intolerant or who refuse surgical management.

It can also be used for oral chemolysis and can potentiate the action of antibiotics.

questions.text: What does Section 200 of the BNS (IPC 166B) deal with?

choices.text: Public servant disobeying direction under law
Public servant framing an incorrect document
Unlawful engagement in trade by hospital

questions.solution:
Section 200 of the BNS (166B IPC) deals with the non-treatment of victims by hospitals. Non-treatment of the victim by the hospital is in direct violation of Section 397 of BNSS (Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita) [357C CrPC].

BNS 199 (IPC 166A) deals with public servants disobeying direction under law.

BNS 201 (IPC 167) deals with public servants framing an incorrect document with an intent to cause injury.

BNS 202 (IPC 168) deals with public servants unlawfully engaging in trade.

A comparison of Sections 199 and 200 of the BNS is given in the table below:

Section

200 BNS/ 166B IPC

Deals with

Public servant disobeying direction under law

Non-treatment of victim by hospital

Punishment

Imprisonment for a minimum of 6 months which may extend to 2 years and fine

Imprisonment for 1 year or fine or both

Non-Cognizable and bailable

questions.text:
Which of the following nucleotide triphosphate targets ATCase for feedback regulation?

(ATCase - aspartate transcarbamoylase)
questions.solution:
Both cytidine triphosphate and adenosine triphosphate target aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) for feedback regulation.

ATCase, the catalyst for the first reaction unique to pyrimidine biosynthesis, is a target of feedback regulation by two nucleotide triphosphates: cytidine triphosphate (CTP) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP). CTP is an end product of the pyrimidine biosynthetic pathway. It inhibits ATCase, whereas the purine nucleotide ATP activates it.

High levels of ATP can overcome the inhibition by CTP, enabling synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides to proceed even when purine nucleotide (CTP) levels are elevated.

questions.text: Lack of insight is seen in which of the following
questions.solution:
• Lack of insight is seen in psychosis and insight is present in neurosis.
  • Mania is an example of psychosis.
  • Other example of psychosis are schizophrenia,severe depression and bipolar disorder.

questions.text: When does keratinization of fetal skin occur?
questions.solution: Keratinization of fetal skin occurs at 22–25 weeks. Therefore, diffusion across fetal skin does not occur after this period. So fetal plasma does not contribute to amniotic fluid formation after this time period.

questions.text: What is the most common site of vulval cancers?
questions.solution: The most common site of vulval cancer is labia majora > clitoris > labia minora.

questions.text: The contrast material used in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia is _____
questions.solution:
Dianosil is the contrast media used in esophageal atresia, as it does not cause chemical pneumonitis.

In general, contrast media having low osmolarity (eg: iohexol) is safer than contrast media having high osmolarity (eg: gastrograffin, conray 420). However, in special cases of oesophageal atresia, tracheoesophageal fistula or for bronchoscopy, dianosol has been traditionally used. It is a unique lipid-based contrast that has been proven to be safe even if it enters the tracheobronchial tree. But practically it is not used nowadays.

The order of preference for contrast media is as follows - Iohexol > Dianosol > Gastrograffin

Below image shows double contrast barium enema.

questions.text: Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of Purkinje cells.

It occurs in advanced cases of chronic alcoholism. There is a loss of Purkinje cells and proliferation of the adjacent astrocytes between the depleted granular cell layer and the molecular layer of the cerebellum.

questions.text: What is the current GINA recommendation for the prescription of long-acting β-2 agonists in patients suffering from bronchial asthma?

choices.text: In combination with an inhaled anticholinergic
In combination with an inhaled corticosteroid
In combination with a short acting β-2 agonist

questions.solution:
LABA is used in combination with inhalational corticosteroids (ICS), preferably in the form of a combination inhaler.

LABA is never taken alone as it does not treat the underlying chronic inflammation of asthma. Corticosteroids will decrease the underlying inflammation and halt the progression of the disease.

Short-acting β-2 agonists (SABA) can be given as an add-on therapy to the LABA-ICS combination (as-needed therapy).

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which is used to check for dry eye.

Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film. Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Treatment of dry eye includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs).

Other tests for dry eye include: 

  1. Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink and appearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilled in the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp.
  2. Rose Bengal staining is used for the detection of dry, dead epithelium in dry eye.
  3. Tear osmolarity test is performed with an osmometer. 

Other options:

Option B: Ishihara plates are used to test colour vision. They help detect red-green colour blindness. 

Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye. 

Option D: Goldmann's tonometry is used to measure intra-ocular pressure. It consists of a double prism mounted on a slit-lamp.  

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: What procedure is the following device most suitable for?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is the south oral Ring-Adair-Elwyn (RAE) endotracheal tube.

It is preferred for nasal and ophthalmic surgeries because it has a preformed right-angle bend at the level of the teeth so that it does not disrupt the surgical field.

The image below shows south faced oral RAE tube used for surgery.

 

The image below shows a north nasal RAE tube. 

It is preferred in oral surgeries as the tube connector faces towards the patient's head after placement, and the surgical field is not disrupted.  

 

 

Other specialized endotracheal tubes and their uses:

  • Flexometalllic (Armored or reinforced tubes): head and neck surgery
  • Microlaryngeal tubes: laryngeal surgery
  • Double-lumen endotracheal tubes: thoracic surgery

questions.text: In work rooms, the number of air changes per hour must be _________
questions.solution:
The number of air changes in work rooms must be 4 - 6 per hour.

The number of air changes in assemblies must be 4 - 6 per hour.

The number of air changes in drawing rooms or living rooms must be 2 - 3 per hour.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors is most commonly associated with meningeal carcinomatosis?
questions.solution:
Breast carcinoma is commonly associated with meningeal carcinomatosis.

Meningeal carcinomatosis presents as tumor nodules studding the surface of the brain, spinal cord, and intradural nerve roots.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presented with multiple beefy-red ulcers over the labia. Microscopic examination of smear from the lesion showed intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and gram-negative bacteria having a safety pin appearance. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by a gram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis.

Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected, they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resembling keloids.

The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged. New lesions can appear along the lymphatic drainage channels.

The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance of the hypervascular intravaginal tissues. 

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

questions.text: While collecting surveillance data for disease X, you find that the incidence of the disease is zero in your region. Which of the following statements best describes this scenario?

choices.text: Disease is eliminated from the region.
Disease is well controlled in the region.
Disease is eradicated from the region.
Disease shows iceberg phenomenon in the region.

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, as the disease has zero incidence, we can say the disease has been eliminated from the region.

Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required.

Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required.

Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, latent, and undiagnosed cases. The clinical or diagnosed cases are represented by the floating tip of the iceberg and not the submerged portion. As disease incidence is zero here, there are no cases to form the iceberg.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady presented with painless lumps in the right breast. On examination, two lumps of size 6 x 2 cm and 4 x 1 cm were palpated in the upper outer quadrant. Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were felt. On evaluation, there was no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging of this tumor?
questions.solution:
TNM staging of the tumor is T3 N1 M0.

In the given scenario:

  • The bigger lump is 6 cm in size - T3
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes - N1 
  • No distant metastasis - M0. 

In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm). If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump. If lumps are present in bilateral breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
