Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: Which of the following pathological changes occurs in the small vessels of patients suffering from hypertension?
questions.solution:
Hypertension results in hyaline arteriolosclerosis of the small vessels.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis which is the thickening of the vessel wall. It has two variants which are hyaline arteriosclerosis and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

In large and medium-sized arteries, hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the vessel walls, leading to:

  • Dissection
  • Aneurysm formation
  • Cerebrovascular hemorrhage
  • Acceleration of atherosclerosis

questions.text: Liver function tests of a patient show isolated elevation of gamma-glutamyltransferase with other liver enzymes within normal limits. All of the following drugs could be responsible for this finding except:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, penicillin does not lead to elevated gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) levels. 

GGT is a microsomal enzyme. Hence, drugs that are microsomal enzyme inducers can lead to an increase in GGT levels. However, other liver enzyme levels will be normal. Therefore, an isolated rise in GGT level does not indicate cholestatic liver disease.

Drugs that increase levels of GGT are:

  • Barbiturates
  • Carbamazepine
  • Ethanol
  • Griseofulvin
  • Rifampicin
  • Phenytoin

questions.text: Accumulation of which of the following substances is responsible for Farber’s disease?
questions.solution:
Accumulation of ceramide is seen in Farber’s disease.

Farber's disease occurs due to deficiency of ceramidase, which catalyses the breakdown of ceramide to fatty acid and sphingosine. Affected children present with painful joint swelling and nodules, progressive joint deformity, hoarse cry and breathing difficulty, mental retardation and failure to thrive.

questions.text: A 27-yr-old woman, presented to OPD with complaints of joint pain and photosensitivity. On examination, you see a butterfly rash on the face and petechial hemorrhages on the lower limbs. On serology ANA, turns out to be positive. Which of the following is the most likely cause of vasculitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus. The vasculitis occurring in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus is due to immune complex deposition.

Vasculitis is the inflammation of the vessel wall. The various mechanisms that cause vasculitis are:

  • Immune-mediated inflammation- Vasculitis caused by immune-mediated inflammation may occur due to the following factors:
    • Immune complex deposition: Seen in systemic immunological disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
    • Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA): Seen in Wegener's granulomatosis, Churg–Strauss disease, etc
    • Anti endothelial cell antibodies: Implicated in Kawasaki disease
    • Autoreactive T cells
  • Infectious pathogens- by direct invasion, generating immune complexes or triggering cross-reactivity.
  • Physical or chemical injury- from irradiation, trauma, toxins, etc.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

  • Competitive parasitic uptake

    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption

    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss

  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a patient with a dilated pupil not responsive to 1% pilocarpine?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate answer would be a pharmacological block. Antimuscarinic will occupy the receptors and results in non-responsiveness to pilocarpine.

In diabetic third nerve palsy, the dilated pupil is due to the loss of innervation to constrictor pupillae. Muscarinic receptors on constrictor pupillae will be intact resulting in miosis by pilocarpine.

In Adie's tonic pupil, there is denervation hypersensitivity. Pupil responds to even lower concentrations of pilocarpine.

Uncal herniation causes pressure on the third nerve leading to ipsilateral mydriasis. But muscarinic receptors are intact and thus the pupil responds to pilocarpine.

questions.text: Where does the nerve passing through the marked foramen derive its parasympathetic preganglionic fibres from?
questions.solution:
The given image shows foramen ovale marked. The lesser petrosal nerve passes through this foramen. It derives preganglionic fibres from the tympanic nerve, also known as Jacobson's nerve. 

Note: Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve also passes through the foramen ovale. However, it does not have any parasympathetic pre-ganglionic fibres.

questions.text: A patient with stress incontinence required surgical management. While performing a Burch colposuspension, the surgeon approached the space of Retzius. What is this space also known as?
questions.solution:
The space of Retzius is the other name for prevesical or retropubic space.

Burch colposuspension is a procedure done to relieve stress urinary incontinence. If an extraperitoneal approach is selected, the retropubic space is entered by perforating the transversalis fascia layer of the anterior abdominal wall.

Once the retropubic space is dissected, the bladder neck and the vaginal fascia underneath are identified. The bladder is mobilized to the opposite side. At each side of the bladder neck, two to four, preferably non‐absorbable sutures are placed in the space of Retzius.

Note:The presacral space is a retroperitoneal space that lies between the peritoneum of the posterior abdominal wall and the sacrum. It contains the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses. The sacral sympathetic trunk lies against the sacrum’s ventral surface.

questions.text: In a patient with PID, laparoscopy shows the following appearance. What is true about the syndrome this patient likely has?
questions.solution:
The image shows the laparoscopic finding of violin string adhesions that are characteristic of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. It is a form of perihepatitis that occurs in the setting of PID.

It is characterized by right upper quadrant pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder. It rarely occurs in women with acute PID. The pathological mechanism is as follows:

Gonococcal / Chlamydial infection → transperitoneal/vascular spread → inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surfaces → adhesions and fibrosis in the perihepatic region → Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome

Cholecystitis and ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess are the differential diagnoses of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. Violin string adhesions would not be seen in these conditions.

questions.text: Blood pressure is measured in an individual 5 times a day under the same conditions by a new screening test. All 5 readings obtained are the almost same. What is the attribute of a new screening test being described?
questions.solution:
The attribute of a new screening test to yield the same reading when repeated under the same conditions is called reliability.

Reliability is also called precision or reproducibility.

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: A patient with mitral stenosis had to undergo surgery. A pre-anesthetic checkup revealed increased liver enzymes. Which of the following inhalational agents would be most preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Xenon is the preferred inhalational agent in the above given clinical scenario.

Xenon is considered to have minimal effects on the cardiovascular system. It is an inert gas and does not undergo metabolism. Therefore, it does not cause any cardiotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. 

Xenon exerts anesthetic and analgesic effects at various receptors in CNS. The most important actions are:

  • Non-competitive antagonism of NMDA receptor
  • Agonism at the TREK channel (a member of two-pore K+ channel family)

Options B and D: Enflurane and sevoflurane (fluorinated anesthetics) decrease arterial blood pressure (due to systemic vasodilation) and cardiac output.

Option C: Halothane is hepatotoxic.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is admitted with nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. On evaluation, he is hypotensive and has mucosal hyperpigmentation. Laboratory workup reveals the diagnosis of hypoaldosteronism. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with hypoaldosteronism, alkalosis is least likely to be found. Hypoaldosteronism is rather responsible for causing metabolic acidosis.

Patients with hypoaldosteronism have:

  • Hyponatremia- due to increased Na+ loss in urine 
  • Hyperkalemia- due to K+ retention 
  • Hypotension- due to reduced ECF volume 
  • Mild metabolic acidosis because hydrogen ions are not secreted in the urine

questions.text: What is the most common cause of primary nephritic syndrome?
questions.solution:
IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is the most common cause of primary nephritic syndrome in the world.

Nephritic syndrome is characterized by:

  • Acute onset of hematuria 
  • Urinalysis - red cell casts 
  • Diminished glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (oliguria)
  • Mild to moderate proteinuria
  • Hypertension
  • Azotemia

Related Pearl: Most Commons in Glomerulopathies

Most common cause of:
Primary glomerulonephritis in the world IgA nephropathy
Secondary glomerulonephritis in the world Diabetic nephropathy
Nephrotic syndrome in adults Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis > membranous nephropathy
Nephrotic syndrome in children Minimal change disease
Glomerulopathy in colon cancer or lung cancer Membranous nephropathy
Renal pathology in leprosy Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
Renal pathology in syphillis Membranous nephropathy
Renal pathology in hepatitis C Cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man was started on heparin postoperatively for thromboprophylaxis. After a week he developed sudden difficulty in breathing. His platelet count was found to be 70,000/microliter. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Alternative anticoagulant such as argatroban should be administered
Low molecular weight heparins should be avoided
Heparin should be replaced with warfarin

questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Direct thrombin inhibitors, such as argatroban is the anticoagulant of choice in HIT.

Management of HIT:

  • Stop heparin/LMWH
  • Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban
  • Do not give platelet transfusions (it only worsens the consumptive coagulopathy)
  • Do not give warfarin until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal.

Increased thrombin generation associated with HIT can cause consumption of protein C. Warfarin administration can further decrease protein C levels and cause skin necrosis. Therefore warfarin is avoided in HIT.

questions.text: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of______
questions.solution:
Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts.

The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine (terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day.

The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.

questions.text: As a 1st year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify the facial nerve trunk.  All of the following structures can be used for its localization except:
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for the identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric- The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Mastoid process- Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
  • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process- The facial nerve lies superficial to it.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
  • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
  • Temporal branch

The given image points to the facial nerve (marked by arrow).

questions.text:
Arrange the following phases of lung development and maturation in order, from the earlier phase to the later phase.

1. Saccular phase
2. Embryonic phase
3. Canalicular phase
4. Pseudoglandular phase
questions.solution:
The correct order of phases of lung maturation is as follows: embryonic, pseudoglandular, canalicular, saccular phase.

The development and maturation of the lungs occur mainly in the following phases:

Phase Developmental events
Embryonic phase (0–7 weeks) Appearance of lung buds and the main pulmonary arteries
Pseudoglandular phase (7–17 weeks) Development of airways and blood vessels to the level of the acinus
Canalicular phase (17–27 weeks) Formation of respiratory airways and the development of the blood-air barrier
Saccular phase/ Alveolar phase (28–32 weeks to after birth)

Development and secondary septation of alveoli

Adjacent capillary networks fuse to form an extensive double capillary network

questions.text: In NREM sleep, which part of brain is not involved?
questions.solution:
The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the Raphe nuclei of ARAS is rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce arousal. Thus, the dorsal raphe nucleus is not involved in NREM sleep.

Genesis and Regulation of NREM sleep

  • Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region rapidly induces sleep mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons called the NREM-on cells.
    • These cells are thought to produce sleep by inhibiting the histaminergic cells in the posterior hypothalamus as well as cells of the nucleus reticularis pontis oralis in the midbrain that mediate arousal.
    • They are maximally active in NREM sleep and inactive during waking and REM sleep.
  • NREM sleep is produced by synchronized synaptic potentials in cortical neurons generated by the rhythmic firing of thalamic relay neurons that project to the cortex. (Thalamocortical loop)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a water-washed disease?
questions.solution:
Cholera is a water-borne disease and not a water-washed disease.

The diseases which are transmitted by improper hygiene and are widely related to circumstances where there is inadequate water supply are called water-washed diseases. 

Some examples of water-washed diseases are:

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Trachoma
  • Scabies
  • Typhus

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to your clinic with photosensitivity, redness, and watering of the eyes for the last 2 days. She shows you this photo of a swelling in her hand that had arisen 2 weeks back but disappeared in just 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Photosensitivity, redness, and watering of the eye with the image showing Calabar swelling is suggestive of loiasis caused by Loa loa.

Loa loa is transmitted by the bite of Chrysops species (deerflies). The infective form is the third-stage microfilarial larva. After entry into human skin, it grows into an adult worm and migrates in subcutaneous tissue. Patients present with Calabar swellings, which are temporary foci of inflammation (angioedema and erythema) that appear as Loa loa wanders through the subcutaneous tissues. They are up to 3 cm in size and are also called fugitive swellings because they disappear in a few days only to reappear elsewhere. Ocular manifestations occur when the worm reaches the subconjunctival tissue during its wanderings. They include granuloma in bulbar conjunctiva, painless edema of the eyelids and proptosis.

The image below shows Calabar swelling.

The image below shows a live, adult Loa loa in the anterior chamber of the eye.

questions.text: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by ______.
questions.solution:
The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by Caldwell and Moloy.

The greatest transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet divides the pelvis into anterior and posterior segments. The shapes of these segments help classify the pelvis as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

Option B: McAfee and Johnson's regimen is for the conservative management of placenta previa.

Option C: Page's and Sher's classification system is used to grade abruptio placentae. 

Option D: Burns and Marshall maneuver is used in breech delivery.

questions.text: What are sirtuins?
questions.solution:
• Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. These include proteins that inhibit metabolic activity, reduce apoptosis, stimulate protein folding, and inhibit the harmful effects of oxygen free-radicals.
  • They help adapt to various environmental stresses, including food deprivation and DNA damage and hence sirtuins are thought to increase longevity. 
  • Sirtuins also increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism and maybe target for the treatment of diabetes
  • Caloric restriction also increases sirtuins production

questions.text: SIADH is not observed in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Primary pulmonary emphysema is not a cause of SIADH. Respiratory causes of SIADH include asthma, pneumothorax and positive-pressure respiration.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the ER after she faints at home. Her husband says that she is very body-conscious and does intermittent fasting. She has been on a vegan diet for the past 2 months. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 6 g/dL

MCV - 67 fL

MCH - 24 pg

RDW - elevated

TIBC - high

Peripheral smear - target cells noted
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia due to the following findings: 

  • Low MCV (N: 87-96 fL) 
  • Low MCH (N: 27-33 pg)
  • Elevated RDW 
  • High TIBC

Option A: Anemia of chronic disease is associated with low TIBC.

Options B and D: Anemia due to B12 and folate deficiency presents with a high MCV (macrocytosis).

questions.text: The following diagram shows an intermuscular space which allows auscultation of apical segments of lower lobes of lung clearly. Which of the following is true about this space?
questions.solution:
The above space is the triangle of auscultation.

  • 6th rib

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Averbuch’s chemotherapy protocol?
questions.solution:
Vinblastine is not included in Averbuch’s chemotherapy protocol for the treatment of malignant pheochromocytoma.

Related Pearl: Averbuch’s Chemotherapy Protocol for Malignant Pheochromocytoma

  • Averbuch’s chemotherapy protocol for malignant pheochromocytoma includes
    • Dacarbazine (600 mg/m2 on days 1 and 2)
    • Cyclophosphamide (750 mg/m2 on day 1)
    • Vincristine (1.4 mg/m2 on day 1)
  • All repeated every 21 days for three to six cycles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who came for a routine check-up was incidentally found to have a late systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click. Echocardiography revealed thickening and redundancy of mitral leaflets with bulging into the left atrium. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and echocardiography findings are suggestive of mitral valve prolapse (MVP) or Barlow syndrome. It is not associated with degenerative calcified deposits (seen in calcific valvular degeneration, not MVP).

Barlow syndrome is more common in females. It may be an isolated condition or less commonly can be associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome.

In this condition, there is mitral annular dilatation with floppy mitral valve leaflets. They prolapse or balloon back into the left atrium during systole. The following pathological changes are seen:

  • Interchordal ballooning (hooding) of the mitral leaflets
  • Thick, rubbery, redundant leaflets 
  • Thickened mural endocardium

The main histologic change is marked thickening of the spongiosa layer with deposition of mucoid called myxomatous degeneration.

Most individuals diagnosed with MVP are asymptomatic. On auscultation, a mid-systolic click, sometimes followed by a mid to late systolic murmur is heard. Chest pain mimicking angina and dyspnea occur rarely.

The complications include:

  • Infective endocarditis
  • Mitral insufficiency
  • Stroke or other systemic infarcts
  • Arrhythmias
  • Sudden cardiac death (rarely)

questions.text: What type of glycoprotein is collagen?
questions.solution:
Collagen comes under glycoprotein sub-classes of O-glycosidic linkages.

Glycoproteins can be divided into three main groups:

  • O-linked: They contain an O-glycosidic linkage. Examples include mucin, proteoglycans, collagens, nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 
  • N-linked: They contain an N-glycosidic linkage. The types of N-glycosidic linkage include complex, hybrid and high-mannose types. 
  • Glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored (GPI-anchored): Examples include acetylcholinesterase, alkaline phosphatase, decay-accelerating factor, 5′-Nucleotidase, thy-1 antigen and variable surface glycoprotein (Trypanosoma brucei).

questions.text: Which of the following cases of esophageal perforation will you not manage surgically?

choices.text: Crepitus in the neck and difficulty breathing after nasogastric tube insertion
Severe chest pain and breathing difficulty following several episodes of vomiting
Septic shock due to pyothorax and mediastinitis on left side of lower esophagus
Epigastric pain radiating to the shoulder with air under the diaphragm

questions.solution:
The patient with crepitus in the neck and difficulty breathing after nasogastric tube insertion most likely has perforation of the cervical esophagus. Instrumental perforations in the cervical esophagus are usually small and can nearly always be managed conservatively.

Esophageal perforation is mostly due to spontaneous or iatrogenic causes. Iatrogenic instrument-induced perforation is the most common cause of esophageal perforation and is most common in the cervical esophagus in the cricopharyngeal area.

Clinical features include pain as the most common presentation. Crepitus may be present. Hamman sign is heard during auscultation which is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat.

Investigations include: 

  • X-ray chest
  • CT scan
  • Esophagogram
  • Thoracentesis
  • Serum amylase level may be raised.

Treatment is primary closure within 24 hours of injury and conservative treatment in selected cases.

Complications of esophageal perforation are pneumothorax and empyema (most common in the left side of the chest and bilateral in 10% of cases).

Consideration for intervention in esophageal perforation

Indications for non-operative management

Indications for operative management

Small septic load

Large septic load

Minimal cardiovascular upset

Septic shock

Confined to mediastinum

Pleura breached

Perforation of cervical esophagus

Perforation of the abdominal esophagus

Perforation by flexible endoscope

Boerhaave’s syndrome

Option B: The patient with severe chest pain and breathing difficulty following several episodes of vomiting most likely has Boerhaave syndrome which affects the lower third of the esophagus and requires primary closure within 24 hours of the injury for a better prognosis.

Option C: Patients presenting with septic shock due to an infection in the chest (pyothorax or mediastinitis)  following an esophageal perforation require emergency surgical stenting, debridement, or drainage. 

Option D: The presence of epigastric pain radiating to the shoulders with air under the diaphragm point to a diagnosis of abdominal esophagus perforation. It requires immediate surgical intervention to restore the integrity of the esophagus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma?

choices.text: Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for PAX 5
It  is uncommonly associated with Epstein Barr Virus
Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for CD45

questions.solution:
Reed–Sternberg cells in nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) are negative for CD45. It is the most common variant.

These are characterized by the presence of lacunar variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the deposition of collagen bands. These bands divide involved lymph nodes into circumscribed nodules.

The Reed-Sternberg cells are found in a polymorphous background of T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are often uncommon.

The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for PAX5 (a B-cell transcription factor), CD15, and CD30, and negative for other B-cell markers, T-cell markers, and CD45 (leukocyte common antigen). This subtype is uncommonly associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).

Involvement of the spleen, liver, bone marrow and other organs and tissues can occur later in the disease. 

The prognosis is excellent.

questions.text: What is the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Lungs are the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma. 

It is followed by the vagina, brain, liver, bone, and kidney in descending order of frequency.

Gestational choriocarcinomas are malignant neoplasm of trophoblastic cells derived from a previously normal or abnormal pregnancy, such as an extrauterine ectopic pregnancy. The hCG levels are elevated to levels above those encountered in hydatidiform moles. It shows hematogenous spread. It is rapidly invasive and metastasizes widely.

Gestational choriocarcinomas are chemosensitive whereas non-gestational choriocarcinomas are chemoresistant.

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except ______

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the ɣ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.solution:
In decerebrate rigidity, there is rigidity in extensor muscles of all the four extremities (not all muscles of the body).

Decerebration

  • Complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculi permits the brain stem pathways to function independently of their input from higher brain structures. This is called a mid-collicular decerebration.
  • This lesion interrupts all input from the cortex (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and red nucleus (rubrospinal tract), primarily to distal muscles of the extremities.
  • The excitatory and inhibitory reticulospinal pathways (primarily to postural extensor muscles) remain intact.
  • The dominance of drive from ascending sensory pathways to the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leads to hyperactivity in extensor muscles in all four extremities which are called decerebrate rigidity.
  • The excitatory input from the reticulospinal pathway activates γ-motor neurons which indirectly activate α-motor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity). This is called the gamma loop.

Option 4. Spinal shock is different from decebrate rigidity as it is a transient state that can occur immediately after a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by a temporary loss or depression of spinal reflexes below the level of the injury.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in the colposcopic biopsy of a patient with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia?
questions.solution:
The basement membrane is intact in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).

Features of CIN:

  • Varying degree of dysplasia
  • Altered nuclear-cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Mitotic figures
  • Intact basement membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following drug cannot be used in treatment of endometriosis is associated with elevated liver enzymes and adverse lipid profile
questions.solution:
Danazol is contraindicated in liver dysfunction.

Side effects of danazol:

weight gain, hirsutism, excessive sweating, muscle cramps, depres­sion, atrophy of breasts and vaginal epithelium, lower­ing of HDL, and liver and renal damage.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with a single painless papule on his penis with no enlarged lymph nodes. A smear was made from the lesion and stained with Wright- Giemsa stain which showed the finding as shown in the following picture. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears indicate a diagnosis of donovanosis caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells (called Pund cells).

Klebsiella granulomatis shows bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a safety pin appearance.

Bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) is shown by:

  • H. ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei
  • Burkholderia mallei

questions.text: The principle that “ In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor” is known as ______
questions.solution:
The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell–Magendie law.

Laws in Sensory Physiology

  • Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
  • Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor.
  • Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
  • Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.

questions.text: A patient has chronic cough with occasional blood in the sputum. He has a history of significant weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following media cannot be used to culture the organism causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough and hemoptysis with a concurrent history of significant weight loss and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. McLeod's medium is not used to culture M. tuberculosis. It is a selective medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis include:

  • Solid- Loeffler's medium is a serum-containing solid medium used for the culture of M. tuberculosis. Other solid media used include Lowenstein- Jensen medium, Dorset medium, Tarshis medium, and Pawlowsky's medium.
  • Liquid- Middlebrook’s media are used for the preparation of antigens and vaccines and in sensitivity testing.  Other examples of liquid mycobacterial culture media include Dubos' medium, Sula's medium and Sauton's medium.
  • Automated culture methods: 
    • BACTEC 460- uses radioisotopes for detection
    • BacT alert- colorimetric method of detection
    • BACTEC MGIT- fluorometric detection method.

questions.text: Which factor forms the basis of co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Protein A forms the basis of the co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus.

Protein A bearing staphylococci are coated with IgG antiserum. Protein A binds to the Fc terminal of IgG, leaving the Fab terminal free to combine with its specific antigen. The corresponding antigen is then added to this mixture which causes agglutination of the bacteria. This is known as the co-agglutination reaction. It is used for streptococcal, gonococcal or hemophilus typing.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady on oral combined contraceptive pills misses a single dose and reports to you in the OPD the next morning. What will be the most appropriate advice to this patient?

choices.text: Continue taking the next dose as scheduled
Double the next dose to make up for the missed dose
Interrupt the course and start taking the medications again on 5th day of bleeding
Start a fresh course of OCP again

questions.solution:
The most appropriate advice for this patient who has missed a single dose of the oral contraceptive pill (OCP) is to double the next dose to make up for the missed dose.

Missed dose considerations for oral combined contraceptive pills:

  • If a single dose is missed - a double dose can be taken on the next day to make up for the missed dose.
  • If two or more doses are missed on subsequent days - the last missed pill has to be taken along with the present pill and alternative methods of contraceptive must be used for the next 7 days.
  • If the pills were missed on the last week (days 15-21) - omit the hormone-free interval by finishing the hormonal pills in the current pack and starting the new pack from the next day.

questions.text: A 30-year-old African farmer presents with Winterbottom’s sign. This sign is due to the involvement of:
questions.solution:
Winterbottom’s sign is due to the involvement of posterior cervical nodes. It is seen in African trypanosomiasis.

African trypanosomiasis is a vector born disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense/rhodesiense. It is transmitted through the bite of a Tsetse fly.

The clinical syndrome includes hemolymphatic disease with associated Winterbottom's sign and a maculopapular rash primarily involving the trunk. At a later stage, the patient can present with features suggestive of meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about adjuvants in vaccines?

choices.text: Immune response is increased by degree or duration by their use
They are used in HPV vaccines
There is a high incidence of side effects with their use
They help in the reduction of amount of immunogens in vaccines

questions.solution:
Side effects are rare with the use of adjuvants in vaccines. 

Adjuvants are substances that are added to vaccines to enhance their immunogenicity by degree and/or duration. They help in the reduction of the amount of immunogen in vaccines or in the number of doses required to achieve immunity.

Aluminium salts are the most commonly used adjuvants.

Adjuvants are used in many vaccines like:

  • Anthrax vaccine
  • Hep A vaccine
  • Hep B vaccine
  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine
  • DT and DTaP
  • HPV vaccine
  • Pneumococcal vaccine

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady who was a victim of rape was brought by the lady constable to the gynecologist for examination. During the genital examination, the doctor obtained a sample from in and around the vagina. What test needs to be done on this sample to identify the presence of semen?
questions.solution:
The acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains.

The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations up to 36 hours after its deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. The acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case of the absence of demonstrable sperms or aspermia. 

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 3-year-old child has a history of fever and the rash, as shown in the image, since 2 days. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 most classically causes erythema infectiosum (also called fifth disease), a mild febrile illness with rash.

Clinical features include prodromal symptoms, such as fever, coryza, headache, nausea, and diarrhea. These constitutional symptoms coincide with the onset of viremia.

Two to five days later, the classic erythematous malar rash appears with relative circumoral pallor (the so-called slapped cheek rash). This facial rash is often followed several days later by a reticulated or lacelike rash on the trunk and extremities.

It is also referred to as "fifth disease" because it was fifth in a list of historical classifications of common skin rash illnesses in children.

Parvovirus can cause transient aplastic anemia in individuals with hematologic abnormalities.

Measles

3rd disease

questions.text: Feline esophagus is a feature of _____
questions.solution:
The presence of linear furrows and multiple corrugated rings throughout a narrow esophagus is known as feline esophagus which is characteristic of eosinophilic esophagitis.

The diagnosis requires biopsy with a histologic finding of > 15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

questions.text: The PARK procedure is used in the correction of which of the following?
questions.solution:
PARK is a technique used for correcting astigmatism.

Photo-astigmatic refractive keratotomy (PARK) is performed using excimer laser for the correction of astigmatism. The other surgical procedures used for correction of astigmatism are astigmatic keratotomy, LASIK and SMILE.

questions.text: A kidney biopsy sample is obtained from a patient with high suspicion of amyloidosis. All of the following can be used to stain this sample, except:
questions.solution:
Sudan Black is used for staining lipids, not amyloid.

Staining for amyloid:

  • Congo red - most widely used and specific 
  • Iodine staining -
    • Used for unfixed specimens or histological sections
    • Amyloid stains mahogany brown and turns violet on adding sulfuric acid
  • Thioflavin T and S -
    • Secondary immunofluorescence with ultraviolet light
    • Thioflavin T is useful for demonstrating the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney
  • Metachromatic stains (crystal violet and methyl violet) - rose-pink appearance.
  • Periodic-acid Schiff (PAS) positive

The image given below shows the amyloid appearance on congo red under plain microscopy.

questions.text: What type of ring structure is present?
questions.solution:
• The bicyclic nucleic acid base ring systems are purines and the monocyclic ring systems are pyrimidines.
  • Quinoline and naphthalene ring systems are not present in nucleic acids.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to dystrophin-glycoprotein complex?
questions.solution:
Perlecan is a large extracellular matrix proteoglycan that plays a crucial role in tissue development and organogenesis.

Dystrophin-glycoprotein complex

  • The dystrophin-glycoprotein complex provides a structural link between the cytoskeleton of the muscle cell and the extracellular matrix, which appears to stabilize the sarcolemma, adds strength to the muscle by providing a scaffolding for the fibrils and prevents contraction-induced injury (rupture).
  • Organisation of DG complex
    • Dystrophin connects F-actin to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan via smaller proteins called Syntrophins.  
    • This β-dystroglycan, in turn connects to the merosin subunit of laminin 211 in the extracellular matrix via α-dystroglycan. 
    • The dystroglycans are also associated with a complex of four transmembrane glycoproteins, α-, β-, γ-, and δ-sarcoglycan and sarcospan.

 

APPLIED ASPECT

  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
    • X-linked recessive disorder
    • Deletion of DMD gene which codes for Dystrophin
  • Becker muscular Dystrophy
    • Dystrophin is present but altered or reduced in amount
  • Limb Girdle Dystrophy
    • Sarcoglycan is mutated

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Meniere’s disease presented with a history of sudden fall without loss of consciousness and no associated neurological or cardiovascular symptoms. On examination, there were no neurological deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis.

Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Its pathogenesis is not well understood.

Tullio phenomenon: It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Lermoyez syndrome: Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of dementia?

choices.text: Immediate retention and recall is normal

questions.solution:
Impaired consciousness is hallmark of delirium which is an acute condition. Dementia presents more commonly with loss of memory and intellectual abilities.

Treat the underlying medical cause

questions.text: After initiation of levodopa therapy, a 55-year-old patient starts experiencing adverse effects. Which of these side effects is not decreased by the addition of carbidopa?
questions.solution:
Behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares, delusions, postural hypotension are not reduced after the addition of carbidopa.

In fact, they are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitors. This is because higher levels of dopamine are formed in CNS.

The combination of levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitors like carbidopa inhibits peripheral adverse effects of dopamine. This decreases the adverse effects like:

  • Anorexia, nausea, and vomiting 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • On and off effect of motor performance

questions.text: The novel free-radical scavenger  approved for use in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is
questions.solution:
Edaravone is a free-radical scavenger newly approved for use in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

Edaravone is a free radical scavenger that is thought to reduce oxidative stress, which has been implicated in the pathogenesis of ALS. Edaravone was found to slow functional deterioration in some patients with ALS. 

It is recommended as an adjunct to riluzole for all patients with ALS.

questions.text: Which of the following tools of recombinant DNA technology is incorrectly paired with its use?

choices.text: DNA polymerase - copies DNA sequences in the polymerase chain reaction
DNA ligase - enzyme that cuts DNA, creating sticky ends
Reverse transcriptase - production of cDNA from mRNA

questions.solution:
DNA ligase is not paired correctly with its use for cutting DNA and creating sticky ends. DNA ligase joins the adjacent nucleotides in a covalent linkage.

Restriction endonucleases cut DNA at specific sites creating sticky ends.

Related Pearl: Some Enzymes Used in Recombinant DNA Research

Enzymes

questions.text: While at a bakery, a man complains of giddiness and palpitations. As the only doctor there, you're asked for help. The man says he had just taken his diabetic medications and shows a prescription listing insulin and acarbose. What would you give for immediate management?
questions.solution:
Giddiness and palpitations after taking insulin and acarbose are suggestive of hypoglycemia. Honey is the most suitable agent among the given options for the management of hypoglycemia in a patient who is on acarbose therapy.

Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It inhibits the intestinal degradation of starch and disaccharides into glucose. Honey contains monosaccharides (fructose and glucose) that do not need to be broken down and are directly absorbed and would be beneficial in hypoglycemia caused by alpha-glucosidase inhibitors. However, glucose or dextrose tablets is recommended when available.

While alpha-glucosidase inhibitors themselves do not cause hypoglycemia, the risk of hypoglycemia is increased when they are taken along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.

Disaccharides and complex carbohydrates will not be completely broken down and absorbed in a patient who is on alpha-glucosidase inhibitors.

Option B - Bread predominantly contains complex carbohydrates like starch

Option C - Sugar contains sucrose, a disaccharide

Option D - Cake contains sugar (disaccharide) and other complex carbohydrates

The U.S. FDA approved Baqsimi nasal powder (3 mg), the first glucagon therapy approved for the emergency treatment of severe hypoglycemia that can be administered through a single-use dispenser (without an injection).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, with oliguria for 3 days. He also complained of feeling drowsy and confused while working. He also complains of episodes of breathlessness and chest pain. On examination, swelling around the eyes and both ankles was noticed. RFT was done and serum creatinine was found to be 2.28 mg/dl(Normal 0.7-1.3 mg/dl). A diagnosis of AKI was made. The patient comes under AKI staging ______.
questions.solution:
The patient comes under acute kidney injury stage 1 of the KDIGO classification as the serum creatinine is increased 1.75 times the normal value.

KDIGO criteria classify AKI on the basis of an increase in serum creatinine and/or decrease in urinary output.

  • Stage 1 – Increase in serum creatinine to 1.5 to 1.9 times baseline, or increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL or reduction in urine output to <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6 to 12 hours.
  • Stage 2 – Increase in serum creatinine to 2.0 to 2.9 times baseline, or reduction in urine output to <0.5 mL/kg/hour for ≥12 hours.
  • Stage 3 – Increase in serum creatinine to 3.0 times baseline, or increase in serum creatinine to ≥ 4.0 mg/dL or reduction in urine output to <0.3 mL/kg/hour for ≥24 hours, or anuria for ≥12 hours, or the initiation of renal replacement therapy.

questions.text: Renal glutaminase activity is increased in
questions.solution:
The activity of renal glutaminase increases in metabolic acidosis.

The increased renal synthesis of ammonium and bicarbonate ions from plasma glutamine is an essential compensatory response to the onset of metabolic acidosis.

Increased renal excretion of ammonium ions provides an expendable cation that facilitates the excretion of acids while conserving sodium and potassium ions.

In contrast, the resulting bicarbonate ions are selectively transported across the basolateral membrane to compensate partially for the decrease in plasma pH and bicarbonate ions.

During chronic acidosis, the increased catabolism of glutamine within the rat kidney is sustained, at least in part, by the cell-specific induction of the mitochondrial glutaminase. This activity is increased 7-to 20-fold, but only within the S1 and S2 segments of the proximal convoluted tubule.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a chronic history of smoking is diagnosed with small cell lung carcinoma. Which of the following statement is false regarding the management of the patient?

choices.text: In wedge resection, anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is removed.
Posterolateral thoracotomy approach is used for surgical resection.
Lobectomy is the treatment of choice for early-stage lung cancer.

questions.solution:
Wedge resection involves the non-anatomical excision of the tumor. Excision of the anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is called segmentectomy.

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a type of tumor that originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells) in the lining bronchial epithelium. They tend to metastasize early to lymph nodes and by the blood-borne spread. 

SCLC is very responsive to chemotherapy such that median survival may be doubled.

Surgery for lung cancers:

Surgery with curative intent is offered to patients with early-stage lung cancer (T1–3, N0–1). Lung cancer resection can be approached through:

  • Posterolateral thoracotomy
  • Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS)

Complications of surgery include:

  • Bleeding
  • Respiratory infection
  • Persistent air-leak
  • Bronchopleural fistula

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with liver disease. The following finding is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis along with intraparenchymal cholestasis, which is suggestive of fatty liver. This condition can occur due to alcoholism.

The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on hematoxylin and eosin staining.

A few causes of fatty liver are as follows:

  • Alcoholism - most common cause in developed countries
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) - associated with diabetes and obesity
  • Toxins
  • Malnutrition
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Anoxia

Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism. It may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys.

The most common form of lipid accumulation is triglycerides. Other forms of lipid that can be accumulated include cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and phospholipids.

questions.text: Deficiency of aspartoacylase leads to:
questions.solution:
Deficiency of aspartoacylase leads to Canavan disease. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder, which leads to excessive excretion of N-acetylaspartic acid in the urine.

It is characterized by leukodystrophy.

Related Pearl: Types of tyrosinemia with deficient enzymes

Disease
Enzyme-deficient

Tyrosine aminotransferase
