questions.text: A teenage boy suffered trauma to his left eye while playing cricket. He is rushed to the ER in severe pain. His X-ray appears as below. What is the characteristic sign noted?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the tear-drop sign. It is seen in orbital floor or blow-out fractures when the orbital contents herniate into the maxillary antrum.

Option B: Phelp’s sign is seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of the normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

Options C and D: Antral and Holman Miller signs are the same. It is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

questions.text: Role of growth hormone in spermatogenesis  is _______
questions.solution:
The growth hormone specifically promotes the early division of spermatogonia.

Hormonal factors that stimulate spermatogenesis:

  • Testosterone, secreted by the Leydig cells of the testis, is essential for growth and division of the testicular germinal cells, which is the first stage in forming sperm.
  • Luteinizing hormone, secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, stimulates the Leydig cells to secrete testosterone.
  • Follicle-stimulating hormone, secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, stimulates the Sertoli cells. Without this stimulation, the spermiogenesis will not occur.
  • Estrogens, formed from testosterone by the Sertoli cells when stimulated by FSH, are also essential for spermiogenesis.
  • Growth hormone is necessary for controlling the background metabolic functions of the testes. It specifically promotes early division of the spermatogonia themselves. In its absence, as in pituitary dwarfs, spermatogenesis is severely deficient or absent, thus causing infertility.

questions.text: In which of the following states will the host not shed the infectious organism?
questions.solution:
The host does not shed the infectious organism in case of a latent infection. This is defined as a state in which the host does not show signs and symptoms of the disease and does not shed the organism.

It can be seen in conditions like herpes simplex, ancylostomiasis, infections due to slow viruses, Brill-Zinsser disease, etc.

Subclinical infection is a state where the host harbours the infectious agent without developing signs and symptoms but sheds the infectious agent. This state is seen in conditions like hepatitis A, rubella, mumps, etc.

Healthy carriers are those who had subclinical infections and later developed a carrier state without suffering from the overt disease. This state is seen in: (mnemonic: CM - DPT)

  • Cholera
  • Meningitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Polio
  • Typhoid

Convalescent carriers are those which shed the infectious agent during the convalescent phase/recovery phase. Such carriers are seen in diphtheria, typhoid, cholera, pertussis, etc.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of cough and fever. Chest X-ray shows obliteration of the right cardiac border. Which anatomical site is likely involved in the pathology?
questions.solution:
Obliteration of the right cardiac border on chest X-ray indicates pathology in the right middle lobe.

This loss of clear demarcation between the normal lung and its surrounding soft structures (heart, diaphragm) is called the silhouette sign. It occurs due to loss of contrast between lungs and soft tissue when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air. This sign may be seen in consolidation, atelectasis, or mass lesions.

In the following images:

  • Left image - red line indicates the normal demarcation between the right heart border and middle lobe of the right lung
  • Right image - loss of demarcation (positive silhouette sign) due to right middle lobe consolidation

Positive silhouette sign and corresponding anatomical site of pathology:

  • Right heart border - right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe
  • Left heart border - lingula segments of the left upper lobe
  • Left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta - left lower lobe
  • Aortic knuckle - left upper lobe (posterior segment)
  • Right hemidiaphragm - right lower lobe
  • Right paratracheal stripe - right upper lobe

questions.text: When an undesired action / behaviour is demonstrated and reward is avoided,it is known as?
questions.solution:
Negative punishment is wherein if the undesired behaviour is manifested the reward is withheld.

Classical conditioning Learning in which a natural response (salivation) is elicited by a conditioned, or learned, stimulus (bell) that previously was presented in conjunction with an unconditioned stimulus (food).

Usually deals with involuntary responses. Pavlov’s classical experiments with dogs—ringing the bell provoked salivation.

Operant conditioning Learning in which a particular action is elicited because it produces a punishment or reward. Usually deals with voluntary responses.

Reinforcement: Target behaviour (response) is followed by desired reward (positive reinforcement) or removal of aversive stimulus (negative reinforcement).

Extinction: Discontinuation of reinforcement (positive or negative) eventually eliminates behavior. Can occur in operant or classical conditioning.

Punishment: Repeated application of aversive stimulus (positive punishment) or removal of desired reward (negative punishment) to extinguish unwanted behaviour (Skinner’s operant conditioning quadrant).

Negative punishment

This happens when a certain desired stimulus/item is removed after a particular undesired behavior is exhibited, resulting in the behavior happening less often in the future.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of RNA polymerase II?
questions.solution:
Synthesis of rRNA is not a function of RNA polymerase II. This is done by RNA polymerase I

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

Types

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA

questions.text: What are the cardinal movements of labour?
questions.solution:
The cardinal movements of labour are engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension, external rotation, expulsion.

(Mnemonic: Every Day FIRE Raises Extremely)

  • Every: Engagement
  • Day: Descent
  • F: Flexion
  • IR: Internal rotation
  • E: Extension
  • Raises: external Rotation
  • Extremely: Expulsion

The most common presentation is cephalic and presenting part is vertex. Head enters the pelvis through transverse diameter majorly and left occipito transverse is the commonest fetal position. Internal rotation of fetal head occurs at the level of ischial spine. In a vertex delivery, the baby's head is delivered by extension and in a breech delivery, the baby's head is delivered by flexion. The best time to give episotomy is after crowning has occured.

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is _____.
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Presumptive coliform count

  • The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium, which are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period of time.
  • The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism or combination of organisms, and the presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed.
  • The proportion of false-positive reactions obtained depends both on the bacterial flora of the water under examination and on the medium used.
  • Lactose broth, or MacConkey's broth, with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator and a standardized concentration of bile salts incubated between 35°C–37°C for 48 hours, seems to be the most suitable media for presumptive tests.

questions.text: The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by:
questions.solution:
The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C. This is called the Reynold Braude phenomenon.

The image given below shows germ tube formation seen in candida species.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; and Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata.  Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, loss of weight, and hair loss. On examination, pallor, nail atrophy, and abnormal skin pigmentation were noted. On endoscopic evaluation, multiple sessile polyps were visualized in the small bowel and colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of intestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, and diarrhea points toward a diagnosis of Cronkhite–Canada syndrome.

It is a non-hereditary polyposis syndrome that occurs at a mean age of 50 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Diarrhea and abdominal pain
  • Nail atrophy, hair loss, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation
  • Cachexia and anemia
  • Characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the stomach, small intestine, and colon due to abnormalities in the nonpolypoid mucosa

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: 500 mg of mannitol was injected out of which 10% is excreted. After equilibrium, plasma concentration is 3.2 mg/100 ml. Calculate ECF Volume (L).
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution can be calculated using the formula:

  • V = volume of compartment
  • Amount injected = 500 mg
  • Amount of indicator excreted = 10% of 500 mg = 50mg
  • Plasma concentration of the indicator = 3.2 mg/100mL

Calculation:

2nd method : 

Mannitol is a substance which leaves blood vessel but can't enter the cell. Therefore, after attaining equilibrium, conc. of mannitol is same in plasma and interstitial fluid 

Therefore, by applying dye-dilution technique, mannitol can be used to measure the volume of ECF (x)

Since, 10% is excreted and 10% of 500mg is 50 mg, the amount of mannitol diluted in ECF is 450 mg (500 - 50) i.e, 450 mg is present in x 

From the given values, 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, which can be re-written as

      3.2/100 = 450/x

Therefore x = 450 * 100 / 3.2 mL

                    = 14,062.5 mL

                    = 14 L

Clinical :

IV Mannitol is used to treat cerebral oedema (since, it doesn't cross cell membrane, it extracts fluid from brain cells), whereas it is contra-indicated in pulmonary edema (here the fluid collection is in the interstitial space)

questions.text: A 70-year-old retiree was employed for two decades in a plastic industry, where he was exposed to vinyl chloride. He is at an increased risk of developing which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Angiosarcoma of the liver is seen in workers who have been exposed to vinyl chloride for prolonged periods.

Angiosarcoma is the most common malignant mesenchymal tumor of the liver. It is a rare and fatal tumor.

They are associated with the following conditions:

  • Hemochromatosis
  • Neurofibromatosis type I
  • Exposure to vinyl chloride, thorium dioxide, and arsenic.

Patients usually present with vague symptoms of abdominal pain, weakness, fatigue, and weight loss. A hepatic bruit is occasionally heard, reflecting the vascular nature of the tumor.

Central hypovascularity, vascular lakes, and peripheral contrast staining on arteriography are suggestive of an angiosarcoma. Biopsy shows the presence of dilated sinusoids lined by atypical endothelial cells.

questions.text: Which is the first steroid to be produced in cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
Lanosterol is the first steroid to be synthesized in cholesterol synthesis.

  • Cyclization of squalene gives rise to the parent steroid, lanosterol.
  • The formation of cholesterol from lanosterol involves changes in the steroid nucleus and the side chain.

Related Pearl: Cholesterol synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following patients is unlikely to have the following finding on a peripheral smear study?

choices.text: A 55-year-old alcoholic man with ascites and jaundice
A 19-year-old girl who underwent emergency splenectomy after a road accident
A 25-year-old man with hemoglobin C disease
A 70-year-old woman undergoing dialysis for the past 3 years

questions.solution:
The black arrows in the given image denote target cells or codocytes. They are RBCs with a dense center (hyperchromic bull's eye) surrounded by an area of pallor. They are not a feature of renal disease (Patient D). 

Target cells are seen in the following conditions:

  • Thalassemia
  • Iron deficiency anemia
  • Liver disease
  • Post-splenectomy
  • Hemoglobin C disease
  • As artifacts in improperly prepared slides

questions.text: A patient presented to the PHC with a deformity as shown in the image below. He fractured his left elbow a few months back which he left untreated. Which of the following features is most likely to be associated with this deformity?

choices.text: Anesthesia over tip of the little finger

questions.solution:
The given image shows cubitus valgus deformity on the left side. It can lead to late-onset ulnar palsy (tardy ulnar nerve palsy) leading to anaesthesia at the tip of the little finger. 

Cubitus valgus deformity is a late complication of non-union of fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus. 

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the finding given in the CT abdomen?
questions.solution:
The given CT abdomen depicts a swirling appearance of the mesentery and superior mesenteric vein around the superior mesenteric artery known as the whirlpool sign or whirl sign, seen in patients with midgut volvulus.

The whirlpool sign is seen when a structure twists upon itself. It is most commonly described in the abdomen where the bowel rotates around its mesentery, with mesenteric vessels creating the whirls. Whirlpool sign is seen in several settings, which include malrotation complicated by midgut volvulus, caecal volvulus, sigmoid volvulus, and closed-loop bowel obstruction. It can also be seen in ovarian torsion.

The marked CECT image below shows the whirlpool sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: The following EEG is that of a 6-year-old girl who is easily distracted in class and exhibits poor scholastic performance. Seizures are precipitated by hyperventilation. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. This is seen in absence seizures.

Absence seizures are characterized by a sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control that lasts only a few seconds. However, there is no post-ictal confusion.

Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and also the seizures.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures.

questions.text: Where does the initiation of nerve impulse occur in a spinal motor neuron?
questions.solution:
In a spinal motor neuron, initiation of nerve impulse occurs in the axon hillock and initial segment of the axon because it has a very high density of voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels. Hence, this region is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential.

Parts of a Neuron:

  • Cell body/perikaryon: contains many Nissl bodies.
  • Dendritic zone where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated.
  • Axon hillock: part of the cell body from which the axon arises.
  • Initial segment: the first part of the axon where propagated action potentials are generated.
  • An axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings. The unmyelinated regions of a myelinated axon are termed as nodes of Ranvier.
  • Synaptic knobs/nerve endings where action potentials cause the release of synaptic transmitters.

Note: Action potentials are generated at the initial segment in spinal motor neurons and the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons.

questions.text: A patient presents with blurring of vision and a painless swelling over his left elbow which has gradually been increasing in size over the past 1 year. On examination, he is noted to have patchy depigmentation on his legs. Which of the following vectors transmits the disease he's suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. It is transmitted by blackfly.

The usual presentation of onchocerciasis is the formation of a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients also present with patchy depigmentation on the legs called leopard skin.

The presence of microfilaria in the eye causes photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestations are sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which can lead to blindness.

Blackfly is also called Simulium. It has a flight range of almost 100 miles, making control of adult flies difficult. Abate is widely used as a larvicidal insecticide. The image given below shows a blackfly.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who has been on dialysis for 2 years presents with bone pain and bowing of legs. Further evaluation reveals hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia. What is the initial treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and hyperphosphatemia in a patient with CKD. Sevelamer is the best initial treatment for this patient. It is a phosphate binder that reduces the absorption of phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract.

Other phosphate binders that can be used include:

  • Calcium containing
    • Calcium acetate
    • Calcium carbonate
  • Non-calcium containing
    • Sevelamer
    • Lanthanum

Calcitriol and cinacalcet are used to decrease PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, they also cause increased serum phosphate levels. Hence, they should not be given as initial treatment in patients with hyperphosphatemia.

Bisphosphonates like pamidronate are used in the treatment of primary hyperparathyroidism.

World Kidney Day is a global health event celebrated annually on the 2nd Thursday in March since 2006. This year, on March 14, the theme is "Kidney Health for All: Advancing equitable access to care and optimal medication practice." The focus is on overcoming barriers like gaps in early diagnosis, limited healthcare coverage, low awareness among healthcare workers, and challenges in medication accessibility and cost. The goal is to promote awareness about the vital role of kidneys and address issues to ensure optimal kidney care worldwide.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph of the patient's pelvis following a road traffic accident reveals upward and lateral dislocation of the left femoral head, accompanied by an obscured lesser trochanter, indicating a posterior dislocation of the left hip.

Posterior hip dislocation is commonly seen following dashboard injuries and the patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity of the lower limb.

Radiological findings:

  • Loss of continuity of acetabulum with the femoral head (break in Shenton's line)
  • Upward and lateral displacement of the femoral head
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen 

The image below shows posterior dislocation with disruption of Shenton's line:

Treatment:

An early reduction should be done as the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis increases with time. 

Closed reduction under sedation or general anaesthesia is done in most cases. If there is an associated femoral neck fracture, a closed reduction should not be attempted as it can lead to the displacement of the femoral neck and disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head.

In closed reduction the following steps are done:

The pelvis is kept in a steady position and traction is applied in line of the femur with the knee flexed at 90 degrees. The hip is then flexed maintaining the traction along with internal rotation and adduction. This is called Allis' maneuver. The below image describes this technique: 

 Other methods of closed reduction include - Stimson's maneuver, East Baltimore lift maneuver, and Bigelow's maneuver. 

 

After reduction, the stability of the hip is tested by flexing the hip to 90 degrees, and a longitudinal and posteriorly directed force is applied. While performing this the joint is monitored in an image intensifier to look for any signs of subluxation. In case of evidence of subluxation or any significant fractures then surgical repair should be done. If there is a delay in surgical correction, skeletal traction with a distal femoral traction pin can be done.

If there is damage to the acetabulum, or intervening structures between the femoral head and the acetabular surface are present - open reduction can be considered. 

Early complications:

  • Sciatic nerve injury - It can be damaged in 10-20% of the cases
  • Vascular injury - Superior gluteal artery tear can occur
  • Concurrent femoral shaft fracture - When both occur together hip dislocation may be missed

Late complications:

  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Myositis ossificans 
  • Secondary osteoarthritis 
  • Recurrent instability

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with complaints of dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. A diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence was suspected. All the following tests can help in the diagnosis of this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
All the above tests can help in the diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence, except the methylene blue 3 swab test. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done for genitourinary fistulae.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction. It is generally due to hypermobility of the urethra, loss of posterior angle, or sphincteric dysfunction. The risk factors include older age, post-menopausal status, multiparity, obesity, smoking,  pregnancy and puerperium, and hereditary conditions which lead to loss of collagen tissue.

Tests done for GSI (Genuine stress incontinence) are:

  • Stress test (Option A): The patient is catheterized after she voids urine and the residual urine in the bladder is measured. Examining for objective evidence of a leak:
    • The patient is asked to squat over a preweighed absorbent pad and is asked to cough and strain.
    • The patient is placed in a lithotomy position and asked to cough and strain for further evidence of a leak.
  • Cotton swab stick test (Option B): A Q tip cotton swab is introduced into the urethra. Initially, the tip of the swab would be horizontal to the floor. Upon straining, in patients without GSI, the tip of the swab would not shift more than 10-15 degrees above the horizontal. In patients with GSI, the tip might go beyond 50-70 degrees from the horizontal.
  • Marshall and Bonney test (Option D): The region of the bladder neck is elevated. If there is no leakage of urine on straining, it indicates a favorable outcome following surgical repair.
  • Urethroscopy.
  • Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry, etc.

Management includes : 

  • Conservative approach: Kegel pelvic floor exercises, magnetic/electric stimulation for nerve injuries, estrogen cream for post-menopausal women, etc
  • Surgical management: The various surgeries include:
    • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz and Pereyra Burch
    • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension
    • Slings
      • Tension-free sling
      • Transobturator type
    • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck

Methylene blue 3 swab test is used to diagnose genitourinary fistulae. Three cotton swabs are placed in the vagina—one at the vault, one in the middle, and one just above the introitus. The methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder through a rubber catheter and the patient is asked to walk for about 5 minutes. She is then asked to lie down and the swabs are inspected. If the swabs are stained with urine and not with the dye, it is indicative of a ureteric fistula. If the lowermost swab is stained blue, it is indicative of a urethral fistula. If the lower 2 swabs are stained blue, it is indicative of a vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: You have been posted as an army medical officer in a military base. Your battalion has suffered injuries from grenade attacks and sustained multiple burns. Which would be the fluid of choice for resuscitating them in the initial 24 hours?
questions.solution:
The fluid of choice for resuscitation in burns patients is Ringer lactate in the first 24 hours followed by albumin and 5% dextrose.

This is in contrast to blunt and penetrating trauma patients in whom colloids (albumin, hydroxyethyl starch) hypertonic saline, and blood are preferred.

Recent Update: The initial fluid rate used for burns resuscitation has been updated by the American Burn Association to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula.

According to ATLS 10th edition,2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA.

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × %TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

questions.text: The given image indicates the diagnosis of ______
questions.solution:
It is composed of sheets of uniform small round cells that are slightly larger than lymphocytes.

They have scant cytoplasm, which may appear clear because it is rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer-Wright rossetes, (tumour cells arranged in a circle about a central fibrillary space) is indicative of neural differentiation.

questions.text: After suffering from a stroke, a middle-aged patient was diagnosed with overactive bladder due to detrusor instability. Which of the following drugs is not useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is not useful in detrusor instability. It is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is efficacious in stress urinary incontinence. It is also indicated in depression, fibromyalgia, and neuropathic pain. 

Muscarinic antagonists are useful in this case. They increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder. 

The effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder are:

  • Lowering of intravesicular pressure
  • Increases bladder capacity
  • Lower the frequency of bladder contractions
  • Alter bladder sensation during filling

questions.text: Chicken fat clots are seen in
questions.solution: Postmortem clots can sometimes be mistaken for antemortem venous thrombi. However, clots that form after death are gelatinous and have a dark red dependent portion where red cells have settled by gravity and a yellow “chicken fat” upper portion, and are usually not attached to the underlying vessel wall.

questions.text:
A young man comes with complaints of intermittent bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after consuming street food during his travel. He is febrile and has RUQ tenderness. Which of the following is the infective form of the likely protozoan causing this disease?

RUQ - Right upper quadrant
questions.solution:
This patient has had bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after eating street food, making a parasite the likely cause of his dysentery. His diarrhea combined with RUQ tenderness indicating a hepatic abscess makes Entamoeba histolytica the causative organism in this case.  The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica causing amoebic dysentery. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

The following are the characteristic features of various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica:

The trophozoite is found only in tissues. Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance. The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance. Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility.

The image below shows the trophozoite form.

The precystic stage has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars. It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst. The cystic stage has a mature cyst with 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. Chromatid bars disappear.

The below image shows cystic form.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suffering a head injury in a road traffic accident. CT revealed a skull base fracture. The fracture line extended along the apex of the petrous bone involving the Dorello's canal. Which of the following cranial nerves is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
The abducens nerve forms the content of Dorello's canal and hence is susceptible to injury in this case.

Dorello's canal is located at the petrous apex of the temporal bone and is formed by the petrosphenoidal/petroclinoid/Gruber's ligament.

questions.text: A randomized control trial showed an effective treatment against an infectious disease. It was then incorporated by the health system. Which of the following is subsequently expected to happen?
questions.solution:
A new effective treatment for infectious disease would reduce the duration of the disease, thereby reducing prevalence.

Note: Both prevalence and incidence decrease but prevalence is the first to show a change in pattern. Hence, ‘prevalence decreases’ is the better answer.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presented with acute chest pain which was stabbing type in nature. The pain is spasmodic and associated with fever spikes. There's an outbreak of coxsackievirus B in her community. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with stabbing type chest pain which is spasmodic in nature, associated with fever spikes, and history of an outbreak of coxsackievirus B is suggestive of Bornholm disease or epidemic pleurodynia or devil's grip. 

Symptoms include paroxysms of acute pleuritic chest pain associated with fever spikes. Involved muscles are tender. Chest X-ray is usually normal. Most cases occur during epidemics of coxsackievirus B. The disease is named after the Danish island of Bornholm where early cases occurred.  

The treatment is non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents or hot fomentation of the involved muscles. 

Other diseases associated with coxsackievirus B:

  • Neonatal myocarditis and pericarditis
  • Juvenile diabetes mellitus
  • Orchitis
  • Severe disseminated congenital infection- hepatitis, meningoencephalitis, adrenocortical involvement

questions.text: The following x-ray was done on a patient with pulmonary tuberculosis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Golden’s S-sign, observed on the given x-ray, represents central focal convexity and peripheral concavity. This radiological finding is typically indicative of a right upper lobe collapse. 

X-ray showing Golden’s S-sign and calcified breast implants:

Golden’s S-sign/reverse S-sign of Golden is named because it resembles a reverse S shape. It can be seen on PA chest radiographs and on CT scans in right upper lobe collapse. 

S-sign can also be seen in bronchogenic carcinoma, primary mediastinal tumour, enlarged lymph nodes, lung metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following is not an autosomal dominant condition?
questions.solution:
Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive inherited disorder of copper metabolism that is characterized by excessive deposition of copper in the liver, brain, and other tissues.

In Wilson disease, the processes of incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin and excretion of excess copper into bile are impaired. The transport of copper by the copper-transporting P-type ATPase is defective due to one of several mutations in the ATP7B gene.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the external auditory canal?

choices.text: Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony part
Furuncles are seen in the cartilaginous part
Fissures of Santorini are present in bony part and permits parotid and superficial mastoid infections to spread to canal
Isthmus is present at junction of cartilaginous and fibrous part

questions.solution:
Furuncles (staphylococcal infection of the hair follicles) are seen only in the outer one-third of the canal since hair is confined to the outer canal.

Skin is also very tightly adherent to the cartilage and hence furuncles are extremely painful.

questions.text: Emotion is regulated by:
questions.solution:
Emotion is regulated by the frontal lobe.

There are two aspects of emotion:

  • Genesis of emotion and rating of emotional importance –from the limbic system – amygdala. 
    • The limbic system houses the emotional association areas, which direct the hypothalamus to express the motor and endocrine components of the emotional state.
    • The amygdala rates the emotional importance of an experience and activates the hippocampus (memory) accordingly. Thus an emotionally intense experience is etched in memory, which is the basis for learned fear responses.
    • Damage to the amygdala ablates the ability to distinguish fear and anger in other persons' voices and facial expressions.
  • Regulation of emotion - frontal lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of chondromalacia patellae?

choices.text: Caused by mechanical stress to patellofemoral joint

questions.solution:
A low Q angle is not a feature of chondromalacia patellae, on the contrary, it has a high Q angle (quadriceps angle).

Q angle is the angle made by the line of the quadriceps pull with the patellar tendon. The line of quadriceps pull extends from the middle of the patella to the anterior superior iliac spine. Normal range is 14-17 degrees. An angle of more than 20 degrees predisposes to anterior knee pain.

This condition is commonly seen in young women and athletes and is mainly caused due to the mechanical overload of the patellofemoral joint.

Patients commonly present with anterior knee pain. The pain is increased by climbing stairs and standing after prolonged sitting. This is known as the theatre sign or movie sign (pain and stiffness after sitting for a long time in a theatre).

It can also be associated with knee swelling and catching sensation (not true locking) of the knee joint.

It is treated conservatively by anti-inflammatory medications, avoiding stressful exercises, and physiotherapy.

questions.text: A critically ill patient who is a registered organ donor collapses even after resuscitative measures. All of the following tests can be used to check the cessation of circulation, except:
questions.solution:
Winslow’s test is used to check the cessation of respiration. In this test a bowl of water is kept on the chest and movement on the surface of the water is noted.

Tests for confirming cessation of circulation:

  • No audible heart sounds on continuous auscultation on the precordial area of the chest for a minimum of 5 minutes and a flat ECG recording for 5 minutes
  • Magnus’s test (Ligature test) - Fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base
  • Diaphanous test (Transillumination test) - Failure to show redness in the webspace between the fingers on transillumination from behind
  • Icard’s test - Fluorescent dye on being injected at a given site in a dead body fails to produce any discoloration
  • Fingernail test - No blanching and filling of blood in the fingernail on the application of pressure and release

Tests for confirming cessation of breathing:

  • No audible breath sounds on continuous auscultation of the upper part of the chest and in front of or on the larynx for a minimum of 5 minutes
  • Feather test – No movement of a feather held in front of the nose
  • Mirror test – Mirror held in front of the nose does not turn dim due to any moisture of breath
  • Winslow’s test – No movement of the surface of the water in a bowl kept on the chest

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.solution:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.

It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. 

Diagnosis:

  • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
  • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.

The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:

  • Grade 1: <50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: No lumen detected

Other options

  • Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.
  • Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.
  • Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male in kidney failure with a serum creatinine of 2.1 mg/dl is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used?
  1. Succinylcholine
  2. Atracurium
  3. D-tubocurarine
  4. Cis-atracurium
  5. Pancuronium
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine, atracurium and cis-atracurium can be used in this patient who has a renal failure with elevated serum creatinine(normal value- 0.8–1.3 mg/dL in men and 0.6–1 mg/dL in women).

Succinylcholine can be safely administered to patients with diminished or absent kidney function provided serum potassium levels are normal. If the serum potassium is increased, then a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant like atracurium or cisatracurium which is non-dependent on renal excretion is to be used. Atracurium or cisatracurium undergo Hofmann elimination which is non-enzymatic spontaneous degradation.

Pancuronium is almost entirely dependent on the kidney for excretion (60–90%). Pancuronium has a prolonged elimination half-life in renal failure patients and thus should be used very cautiously.

40-60% of d-tubocurarine is excreted via the kidney and so prolonged effects are seen with renal insufficiency

 

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text: What sweat excretion rate in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of intolerable air temperature?
questions.solution:
A sweat excretion rate of > 4.5 L /4 hours in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of intolerable air temperature. This is known as McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate.

This is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with the normal physiological reaction of acclimatized, healthy young men who are exposed to heat. The predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR) is obtained from readings of air and mean radiant temperature and air velocity under different work intensities. Based on this value, the zone of comfort can be determined.

Zone of comfort    Predicted P4SR
Comfort zone 1 – 3 litres
Just tolerable 3 – 4.5 litres
Intolerable 4.5 + litres

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), an active form of pyridoxine serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions.

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is a coenzyme for enzymes involved in the following:

  • Transamination
  • Decarboxylation
  • Glycogenolysis: Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Transsulfuration reaction: Cystathionine β-synthase and cystathionase
  • Heme synthesis: ALA synthase (deficiency causes microcytic hypochromic anemia)
  • Tryptophan metabolism: Kynureninase (deficiency causes pellagra-like symptoms)

Note: Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) serves as a coenzyme in many amino acid metabolisms, so its RDA mainly depends on daily protein intake.

questions.text: What parameters are used in calculating discriminant function?

choices.text: Prothrombin time, ascites and hepatic encephalopathy

questions.solution:
Discriminant function (DF) is calculated using prothrombin time and bilirubin level. It is also known as the Maddrey score and it assesses the severity and mortality risk in alcoholic hepatitis. 

DF = 4.6 X (the prolongation of the prothrombin time above control [seconds]) + serum bilirubin (mg/dL)

DF ≥ 32 indicates severe disease and is an indication for starting glucocorticoids.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about natural killer cells?

choices.text: CD16 and CD56 are the surface molecules
They are involved in antibody-dependant cytotoxic killing
IL-12  stimulates the proliferation of NK cells
They activate macrophages by secreting IFN-γ

questions.solution:
IL-2 and IL-15 stimulate the proliferation of NK cells. On the other hand, IL-12 activates the killing of target cells and secretion of IFN-γ.

NK cells are large granular lymphocytes, which constitutes 5% to 10% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CD16 and CD56 are the surface molecules.

Functions of NK cells:

  • Killing of a variety of virus-infected cells and tumor cells, without prior exposure to or activation by these microbes or tumors
  • Secretion of interferon-γ (IFN-γ), which activates macrophages to destroy ingested microbes
  • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) - NK cells express CD16 which is a receptor for IgG Fc tails. Hence, these cells have the ability to lyse IgG-coated target cells. 

ADCC is also seen in immune responses involving neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, etc.

The image given below shows activating and inhibitory receptors of natural killer (NK) cells.

Note: A new group of T cells has been discovered called NK-T cells. These are T cells that contain markers of NK cells. These are important defence mechanisms against microorganisms like Listeria monocytogenes and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding follicular carcinoma thyroid?

choices.text: Occur more commonly in iodine-deficient areas
FNAC is not useful in diagnosis
Treatment is total thyroidectomy with prophylactic nodal dissection

questions.solution:
Treatment is total thyroidectomy only. Prophylactic nodal dissection is not needed in follicular carcinoma as nodal involvement is infrequent. Follicular carcinoma metastazises hematogenously while lymph node metastasis are common in papillary carcinoma.

Total thyroidectomy with prophylactic central neck node dissection is recommended in T3 and T4 papillary carcinoma. (suggested by the 2009 ATA guidelines for thyroid cancer management)

Capsular and vascular invasion indicate malignancy but this cannot be determined using FNAC and hence is not diagnostic.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding transfer factor?

choices.text: The transferred CMI is local at injection site and not systemic
It has been used in the treatment of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
The immunity offered by it is referred to as adoptive immunity

questions.solution:
The transferred cell mediated immunity is not local at the injected site. It is systemic.

The cell-mediated immunity (CMI) can be transferred in human beings by the injection of extracts from leucocytes. This extract is known as transfer factor(TF).

The immunity transferred as a result of injection of the Transfer factor is referred to as Adoptive immunity.

The Cell Mediated Immunity can be transferred only to those antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

TF is dialysable, low molecular weight substance.

Applications of Transfer factor:

  • To restore immune capacity in patients with T-cell deficiency (Wiskott – Aldrich syndrome)
  • Treatment of disseminated infections associated with deficient cell mediated immunity such as Lepromatous leprosy, Tuberculosis Mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • Treatment of Malignant melanoma
  • In treatment of autoimmune diseases such as Systemic lupus erythematosus, Rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign.

In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions. This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign. 

Sonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Single placental mass
  • Presence of intervening membrane - T sign
  • Thin intervening membrane <2mm

The best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34 - 37weeks + 6 days.

Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda sign

Image 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between them

Image 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs

questions.text: When a pheochromocytoma suddenly discharges a large amount of epinephrine into the circulation, the patient's heart rate would be expected to:

choices.text: Increase because the increase in blood pressure stimulates the carotid and aortic baroreceptors
Increase because epinephrine has a direct chronotropic effect on the heart
Increase because of increased tonic parasympathetic discharge to the heart
Decrease because the increase in blood pressure stimulates the carotid and aortic chemoreceptors

questions.solution:
When a pheochromocytoma suddenly discharges a large amount of epinephrine into the circulation, the patient's heart rate would be expected to increase because it has direct chronotrophic effect on heart.

Effect of Catecholamines on Heart

Both epinephrine and norepinephrine –

  • Increase the force and rate of contraction of the heart by β1-receptors.
  • Increase myocardial excitability, causing extrasystoles and occasionally cardiac arrhythmias.

The differences in the effects are given in the table below 

Norepinephrine

Epinephrine

vasoconstriction via α1-receptors

Vasodilatation in skeletal muscle and the liver via β2-receptors. 

Norepinephrine -> Increases systolic and diastolic blood pressures -> stimulation of carotid and aortic baroreceptors -> reflex bradycardia -> overrides cardio acceleratory effect of norepi­nephrine->cardiac output falls.

Epi­nephrine causes a widening of the pulse pressure but because baroreceptor stimulation is insufficient to obscure the direct effect of the epinephrine on the heart, cardiac rate, and output increase.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with polycythemia vera?
questions.solution:
Low WBC count is not a feature of polycythemia vera. It is associated with an elevated WBC count.

Common laboratory findings of polycythemia vera are:

  • Elevated hemoglobin concentration, hematocrit levels, and RBC count
  • Elevated WBCs and platelet counts
  • Low to normal erythropoietin levels
  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion
