questions.text: The following machine was used during a cardiac bypass surgery. How is it best sterilized?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a heart-lung machine. It is best sterilized using ethylene oxide.

Ethylene oxide gas diffuses through many types of porous materials and readily penetrates some plastics and is used for sterilizing machines.

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: In Breslau’s second life test, the organs tested are _______
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test, the organs tested are the stomach and intestine.

BRESLAU’S SECOND LIFE TEST: It is based on the air entering the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water.

Inference:

  • A floating viscera giving out air bubbles when opened underwater is a positive test and suggestive of live birth.
  • False positive – in case of stillbirth, air might enter the stomach when a child tries to free obstruction of air passages.
  • Mucus, saliva and air bubbles in the stomach – breathing has occurred.
  • Only mucus – breathing has not occurred.
  • Blood, meconium, liquor amnii in the stomach – child alive at or shortly before birth.
  • Milk in the stomach – the child was alive for some time after birth.
  • Test is invalid in case of putrefaction.

Other tests for live birth:

  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth.
  • Fodere’s test –Based on the increase in the weight of the lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of an unrespired lung is 30 – 40g, whereas the weight of respired lung is 60 – 66g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs- weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:70.
    • Respired lungs- weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:35

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable criterion for age determination from Gustafson's method?
questions.solution:
Transparency of the root is the most reliable criterion in Gustafson's method.

Gustafson’s method of estimation of age of an individual is based on physiological changes in teeth. It is mainly useful in adults over 25 years of age.

Gustafson’s criteria includes:

  • Attrition -  wear and tear changes of occlusal surface
  • Periodontosis -  regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling
  • Secondary dentin - deposition of dentin in pulp cavity
  • Cementum apposition - deposition of cementum in the root forming incremental lines
  • Root resorption -  involves both cementum and dentin
  • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with mineral and they become less transparent.

questions.text: You are planning to start treatment in a middle-aged man diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. He has a history of chronic kidney disease and his current creatinine clearance is 25 mL/min. Which of the following drugs is least likely to require dose modification?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the least likely drug to require dose modification in renal failure patients as it is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted in bile. 

In patients with renal failure, the half-life of isoniazid will be prolonged, but its adverse effects are not significantly increased. Hence dose modification is not usually done for isoniazid in clinical practice as a reduction in dose may render the regimen ineffective and increase the chances of resistance.

Ethambutol and streptomycin are primarily excreted unchanged through the renal system and need dose modification in renal failure.

This is a controversial question. Upon thorough review, we found that both rifampicin and isoniazid do not require dose adjustment. However, rifampicin would be the single best answer as it has a safer profile in CKD patients.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with facial weakness and pain for the past 2 days. The following signs are seen on examination. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The features are suggestive of lower motor neuron (LMN) type of facial palsy.

In the image, the absence of wrinkling over the right side of the forehead and incomplete closure of the right eyelid is characteristic of LMN type of facial palsy. 

In upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, the upper part of the face is spared due to bilateral UMN innervation. 

Features of facial nerve palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy of facial muscles Absent Present

Note: Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side due to the action of unaffected facial muscles, while drooping occurs on the affected side.

questions.text: Ophthalmoscopy performed on a 14-year-old boy had the given incidental finding. Family history revealed that his grandfather had colon cancer and an aunt was diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. Genetic testing confirmed APC gene mutation. Which of the following is false about his condition?

choices.text: Condition can be passed on to his daughter in the future
Mutation of APC gene is on chromosome 15

questions.solution:
The given image showing a pigmented retina, the patient's family history and APC gene mutation is suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis is due to the mutation of APC gene located on the long arm of chromosome 5 (5q21), not 15.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is autosomal dominant. It is characterized by the presence of >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum. It usually manifests by the late 2nd or early 3rd decade. Although it accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma, the risk of development of cancer is 100%.

CHRPE (Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epthelium) is the earliest extra-colonic manifestation of FAP, present in up to 75% of patients. 

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Identify B lynch suture from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Image 1 depicts B lynch suture. 

All these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose the walls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.

questions.text: A cattle poison named sui is associated with which of the following plant poisons?
questions.solution:
Abrus precatorius is commonly used as a cattle poison in the form of suis.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius are:

  • Abrin
  • Abrine
  • Abralin

Medicolegal importance - It is a commonly used cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as sui (meaning needle in Hindi).

These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

The image given below shows seeds of Abrus precatorius.

questions.text: A young lady who presented with oligomenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed with PCOS. Mutation of which of the following genes can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Mutation of the CYP21 gene can cause polycystic ovarian syndrome.

The gene for 21-hydroxylase (CYP21) is located in the short arm of chromosome 6. Heterozygosity of the gene has been linked to the development of PCOS. Defects in this gene also lead to congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

PCOS and PCOD are two different diseases. In PCOD, the ovaries begin to release immature eggs, resulting in hormonal imbalances and enlarged ovaries, whereas in PCOS, it is an endocrine disorder that causes the ovaries to create excess androgens, making the eggs prone to cyst formation. However, unlike with PCOD, these cysts will not be expelled and will instead accumulate in the ovaries.

questions.text: A patient with a leg injury was treated with a skin graft as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this type of skin graft?

choices.text: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
Healing with abnormal pigmentation are more common.
Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand the surface area that can be covered but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance.

Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin split grafts have a low primary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, they tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability.

Type of graft Split-thickness graft Full-thickness graft
Composition Epidermis + part of the dermis Epidermis + full dermis
Cosmetic appearance Relatively poor Good (texture and pigmentation are better matched)
Graft take/survival High chance of survival Poor (long healing time and vascularization)
Contraction Lesser primary contraction and more secondary contraction More primary contraction and lesser secondary contraction
Use Can cover large areas of defects For areas where least contraction (finger) or best cosmesis (face) is desired

The image given below shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife.

questions.text: A duplex ultrasound was done on a patient with varicose veins. It revealed incompetence of the perforator connecting the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral vein. What is this perforator known as?
questions.solution:
Dodd’s perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral veins. It is also known as ‘above knee’ perforator and is seen at the inferior ⅓ of the thigh. 

Perforating veins connect the superficial venous system to the deep venous system by penetrating the fascial layers of the lower extremity. Although the total number of perforator veins is variable, up to 100 have been documented.

Named perforators:

  • Adductor Canal (thigh) – Hunter's perforator
  • Above Knee – Dodd's  perforator
  • Below Knee – Boyd's perforator
  • Medial Calf – Cockett I, II, and III perforator
  • Ankle - May or Kustner perforator

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is also known as Hamman-Rich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) is also known as Hamman–Rich syndrome.

AIP is a rare, idiopathic, fulminant interstitial lung disease (ILD) that is similar in presentation to ARDS. It is often preceded by a viral upper respiratory tract infection.

Histologically, it shows diffuse alveolar damage. HRCT shows bilateral patchy, ground-glass opacities. Lung biopsy shows diffuse alveolar damage with hyaline formation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is falsely matched?
questions.solution:
Postmortem wounds show no/absent vital reaction because no enzyme activity will be found in a wound sustained after death. This is not the same as a negative vital reaction as it is indicative of decreased enzymatic activity and is seen in antemortem wounds.

Vital reactions are local tissue reactions at the site of tissue damage. Only antemortem wounds show vital reactions as cells are active at the time of wound infliction. The vital reactions of an antemortem wound are of two zones: 

  • Negative vital reaction (decrease in enzymatic activity of wound): It occurs in the central necrotic area, close to the edge of the wound where there is irreversible damage to tissues. 
  • Positive vital reaction (increase in enzymatic activity of wound): It occurs just outside the necrotic area of the wound in order to salvage damaged (but not irreversibly damaged) tissues.

Difference between antemortem and postmortem wounds:

Trait Antemortem wounds   Postmortem wounds
Site Anywhere on the body Usually over bony prominences  
Colour Bright reddish brown Yellowish, translucent, Parchment like 
Exudation More Less 
Microscopic Intravital reaction and congestion seen

No intravital reaction and congestion

questions.text: A psychiatry resident is evaluating a chronic alcoholic patient admitted to the ward. When asked about his day, he correctly remembered that he was wheeled out of the ward, but then went on to tell a story of a trip he made to the nearby park, which did not occur. He also made up random names as he went on talking about his children. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of confabulation. It is one of the features of Korsafkoff’s psychosis. Confabulation is filling up gaps in memory with false stories.

Korsakoff’s psychosis is a chronic amnestic syndrome that can follow Wernicke's encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency (secondary to alcoholism). The cardinal features are impaired mental syndrome and anterograde amnesia. Only 20% of patients recover with treatment (whereas in Wernicke's encephalopathy there is complete reversal with treatment).

Clinical features:

  • Impaired mental syndrome - especially recent memory
  • Striking inability to form new memories - severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia is less severe.
  • Present with confabulation as an attempt to cover the memory deficit
  • There is a lack of insight and no intellectual functional loss.
  • Overall intact intelligence
  • Implicit learning (e.g., learning procedures) is preserved.
  • Long-term and immediate memory is normal.

Treatment: Thiamine is given 100mg orally two to three times daily for 3 to 12 months.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with difficulty to socialise, retarded speech, difficulty in concentrating. Which of the following is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
• A 3-year-old child with difficulty in communication, difficulty in socialising and inability to concentrate should raise suspicion for autism. 2/3rd patients with autistic spectrum disorders also have intellectual disability (mental retardation).
  • Learning disability includes difficulty in specific domains like reading, calculations.

World Autism Awareness Day is observed annually on April 2nd to highlight the need to help improve the quality of life of those with autism so they can lead full and meaningful lives as an integral part of society. The stigmatization and discrimination associated with neurological differences remain substantial obstacles to diagnosis and therapies, an issue that must be addressed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. CT scan of the abdomen revealed the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image shows the Mercedes-Benz sign. It is a characteristic sign seen in gallstones.

In gallstone, rarely, the center of the stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph called the Mercedes–Benz sign (triradiate sign) or seagull sign (biradiate sign).

questions.text: The most common type of congenital cataract with diminished vision is ______.
questions.solution:
Lamellar or zonular cataract is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with visual impairment.

Etiology: It may be either genetic or environmental in origin.

  • Genetic pattern is usually of familial autosomal-dominant variety
  • Environmental form is associated with:
    • Vitamin D deficiency
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Sometimes, maternal rubella infection contracted between the 7th and 8th week of gestation may also cause lamellar cataract.
  • The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear.
  • Small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) may be seen towards the equator.

 

Image: Lamellar cataract

questions.text: Which of these terms is used for paired t tests?
questions.solution:
Paired t tests are also called correlated pairs t test, paired samples t test, or dependent samples t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech), not rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal speech).

The patients present with progressive nasal obstruction and hyponasal speech due to mass in the postnasal space. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation. The patients may be markedly anemic due to repeated blood loss.

Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion occur due to obstruction of the eustachian tube.

It can spread to the orbit giving rise to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog face deformity. Other features include swelling of the cheek and cranial nerve palsies (II, III, IV, and VI).

questions.text: Which among the following is not recommended for routine medical treatment of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Antiproteases like Gabexate & Aprotinin are not recommended for routine medical treatment of acute pancreatitis.

IV fluid resuscitation (Ringers Lactate or Normal Saline ) & IV analgesia with opiates are integral components of the first line of management in acute pancreatitis.

This MCQ has been revised based on current recommendations on the treatment of Acute Pancreatitis as per the references provided below.

questions.text: Which of the following gases is an inhibitor of Complex IV of the ETC?
questions.solution:
H2S is an inhibitor of complex IV of ETC.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: All of the following statements about octreotide are true except_______

choices.text: It is used in diagnostic imaging of Neuroendocrine tumors
It can be used for the management of secretory diarrhoea
It can be used in portal hypertension

questions.solution:
Octreotide is a long acting somatostatin analog. It is a peptide and ineffective orally but can be given either IM/SC/IV.

It can be used in these conditions

  • Decrease secretory diarrhea associated with neuroendocrine tumors like carcinoid and VIPoma (option c)
  • Decrease diarrhea associated with short bowel syndrome, AIDS
  • Pituitary tumors causing acromegaly (option b)
  • Islet cell tumors: to reduce hormonal secretion
  • Acute bleeding in esophageal varices seen in portal hypertension (option d)
  • GI or pancreatic fistula
  • Thyrotrope adenomas

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the opening marked in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The anterior interosseous artery passes through the opening in the interosseous membrane.

The anterior interosseous artery passes distally along the anterior aspect of the interosseous membrane and supplies muscles of the deep compartment of the forearm, radius, and ulna.

Perforating the interosseous membrane in the distal forearm, the anterior interosseous artery terminates by joining the posterior interosseous artery.

The image given below shows anterior interosseous artery.

questions.text: A patient is on methotrexate therapy as part of his chemotherapy regimen. Which of the following tests is not indicated for monitoring in this patient?
questions.solution:
Fundoscopy is not monitored in a patient on methotrexate therapy. This is because no significant eye-related adverse effect is associated with either low, normal or high-dose methotrexate use, mandating frequent monitoring.

Option A - Hepatic fibrosis or cirrhosis is a significant side effect of long-term therapy of methotrexate that requires regular hepatic function monitoring.

Option B - Allergic interstitial pneumonitis and other pulmonary-related adverse effects are associated with methotrexate.

Option D - Myelosuppression is a common and a serious adverse effect that mandates routine monitoring of hemogram.

questions.text: Soret band is seen around the wavelength of _______.
questions.solution:
Soret band is seen around the wavelength of 400nm.

It is a distinguishing feature shared by all porphyrins.

Spectrophotometry can be used to detect porphyrin and its precursors in porphyrias.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation was rushed to the ER with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. Which of the following most commonly leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during puerperium.

Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function. Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected.

Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. 

Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii.

The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.

questions.text: A resident notes the following fundus picture in a patient referred to the ophthalmology OPD with visual complaints. What does it suggest?
questions.solution:
The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema.

Ophthalmoscopic features of papilledema:

  • Early-stage:
    • Obscuration of the disc margins (nasal margins first)
    • Absence of spontaneous venous pulsation at the disc
    • Mild hyperemia of the disc
    • The blurring of the peripapillary nerve fiber layer
  • Established papilledema:
    • The disc appears to be enlarged and elevated (mushroom or dome-shaped)
    • Macular fan appears
    • Paton’s lines- circumferential greyish white folds may develop due to the separation of nerve fibers
    • Visual fields show enlargement of the blind spot
    • Veins become tortuous and engorged
    • Multiple cotton-wool spots and superficial hemorrhages
  • Chronic or long-standing (vintage) papilledema:
    • The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork
    • Small drusen-like crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface
  • Atrophic stage:
    • Secondary optic atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be depicted by the image given below?

choices.text: Rural - urban distributions of a disease

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spot map. Spot maps are not used to depict rural-urban distributions of a disease. They help to understand the local distributions of a disease.

They are also called shaded maps. This method was used by John Snow to investigate the epidemic of cholera in London in 1854. They depict areas of high or low frequency, the boundaries, and patterns of disease distribution.

questions.text: The linear fibrous band formed by interdigitation of the tendinous or aponeurotic ends of the muscles is known as _______
questions.solution:
The linear fibrous band formed by interdigitation of the tendinous or aponeurotic ends of the muscles is known as raphe. 

Unlike most ligaments, the raphe are stretchable. Examples of raphe include:

  • linea alba
  • pterygomandibular raphe
  • mylohyoid raphe
  • median pharyngeal raphe
  • anococcygeal raphe

questions.text: Amussat’s sign is an intimal tear of______
questions.solution:
• Amussat’s sign is an intimal tear of the carotid artery.
  • Important post-mortem findings of hanging:
    • Internal:
      • The fluidity of blood.
      • Tissues under ligature will be dry, pale and glistening.
      • There may be intimal tears of the carotid artery (Amussat’s sign).
      • Fracture of hyoid is seen in 15-20% of cases. Fracture of the thyroid cartilage and tracheal rings may be seen. There may be congestion and ecchymoses in trachea, epiglottis, esophagus, and larynx. All these injuries are more common in strangulation because strangulation is more violent than hanging causing more severe injury to neck structures.

questions.text: A Norovirus outbreak occurs in an urban slum where you are posted as the PHC medical officer. Which is the best method to teach the people about ORS?
questions.solution:
The best method to teach an urban slum about ORS is by demonstrations.

Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task or skill or procedure. It shows the step-by-step process of a task. It arouses interest and incites ‘learning by doing,’ and ‘seeing is believing’ philosophies.

Methods of Health Communication  
Individual approach Group approach Mass approach
  1. Personal contact
  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Role play
  1. TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
The correct order is Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation.

Disaster management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: It involves immediate management of mass casualties as follows:

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery: It involves the restoration of the pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as:

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV positive man presents with an acute onset high-grade fever with chills and shortness of breath. On evaluation, he's diagnosed to have a necrotising mediastinitis secondary to rupture of a retropharyngeal abscess. What is the likely route of spread of infection to the mediastinum?

choices.text: Between  buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia.
Between alar fascia and prevertebral fascia
Between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle

questions.solution:
The likely route of spread of infection is between the alar fascia anteriorly and the prevertebral fascia posteriorly. It is also called the danger space or alar space.

It lies just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. It extends from the skull base to the diaphragm. Infections from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named the danger space.

questions.text: Which of the following is included under threshold disease when screening neonates for retinopathy of prematurity?

choices.text: ROP stage 1 extending from 6'o clock to 11'0 clock in zone 1 with plus disease
ROP stage 3 extending  from 2'o clock to 7'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease
ROP stage 3 extending from 1'o clock to 4'o clock in zone 1 without plus disease
ROP stage 2 extending from 3'o clock to 6'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease

questions.solution:
ROP stage 3 extending from 2'0 clock to 7'o clock (6 clock hours) in zone 2 with plus disease fits into the definition of threshold disease.

Threshold disease of retinopathy of prematurity is defined by the CRYO-ROP study as:

  • Stage 3 disease: Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous
  • Involvement of zones 1 or 2
  • Involvement of either at least 5 contiguous (continuous) clock hours or 8 non-contiguous clock hours
  • Associated with "plus disease": Dilatation and tortuosity of posterior pole vessels in at least two quadrants at the posterior pole. 

 Treatment of threshold disease is laser photocoagulation of the involved part within 72 hours of diagnosis. 

Treatment of the various stages of ROP includes:

  • Pre-threshold type 1 disease - Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours and is done by laser photocoagulation of avascular retina.
  • Pre-threshold type 2 disease (Any ROP not following under type 1)- Observation for progression
  • Threshold disease - Laser photocoagulation of avascular retina
  • Aggresive posterior-ROP- Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents, eg., bevacizumab
  • Tractional retinal detachment (stage 4A) - Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: A diabetic patient is diagnosed with hypertension during his annual health check-up. What is the treatment of choice for him?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors such as captopril or ARBs can be considered as a treatment of choice in hypertensive patients with diabetes because of the renoprotective action. It benefits diabetic patients by reducing the risk of occurrence and progression of diabetic nephropathy. 

They are also recommended in patients with CKD irrespective of diabetes status as they can delay the progression of nephropathy.

Option A: Thiazide diuretics worsen glycemic control and are not preferred in diabetic patients.

Option B: Beta-blockers, especially non-selective blockers, worsen glycemic control.

Option D: Calcium channel blockers have a neutral effect on glycemic control and can be used in diabetes if ACE inhibitors or ARBs cannot be given.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to the ER with severe dehydration and weakness. History was suggestive of multiple episodes of watery diarrhea and non-bilious vomiting since morning. His breath reeked of garlic odor. ECG showed QT prolongation.  Which of the following samples must be collected for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of acute arsenic poisoning. For a definitive diagnosis, the arsenic levels are measured in 24-hour urine samples.

If the baseline urinary level is within normal limits and arsenic intoxication is still suspected, hair and nail clippings should be harvested for laboratory analysis. Due to the rapid distribution of arsenic in tissues, blood arsenic levels are unreliable.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, you note reduced muscle stretch reflexes below the knee along with the following findings. This condition is associated with which chromosome?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease. It is most commonly associated with chromosome 17.

It is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. The most common variant of this condition is CMT1A. It is caused by a duplication of a region on chromosome 17 that includes the peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) gene.

It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop with no numbness or tingling. There is reduced sensation to all modalities with reduced muscle stretch reflexes. Atrophy of the muscles below the knee leads to inverted champagne bottle legs.

questions.text: In patients with trigeminal neuralgia, the nerve is most commonly compressed by ______.
questions.solution:
The superior cerebellar artery most often compresses the trigeminal nerve as it emerges from the brainstem. This causes lancinating pain in the distribution of the nerve which is known as trigeminal neuralgia.

Though trigeminal neuralgia can be diagnosed by the clinical features, MRI is recommended to define the underlying cause. In cases refractory to medical management, it also helps to plan for surgical decompression.

questions.text: A 40-year-man presents with hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension. The resected kidney is as seen below. All are associated with this condition except ______.

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen
Portal fibrosis and proliferation of portal bile ducts

questions.solution:
Clinical history and gross image suggest that the patient has autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). They are associated with cysts in liver, spleen, and pancreas; berry aneurysms; and mitral valve prolapse.

Note: 

Patients with autosomal-recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder
  • Multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure
  • 40% have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease)
  • Cysts in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms arise in the circle of Willis à subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1 and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2
  • Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Management of a juvenile idiopathic primary scoliosis with a curve of the less than 20 degrees is ______

choices.text: Reassurance and no follow up required

questions.solution:
In juvenile scoliosis, a curve<20 degrees requires observation alone.

Management of juvenile scoliosis

  • Curve<20 degrees - Observation
  • Curve 20-50 degrees - Milwaukee bracing.
  • Curve>50 degrees - Surgical correction and fusion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and suffered a head injury. On examination, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated blood pressure in this condition?
questions.solution:
The reflex responsible for elevated blood pressure(BP) in head injury patients is the Cushing reflex.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

questions.text: The recurrence rate for breech presentation in the second pregnancy following a breech delivery is
questions.solution: Specifically, following one breech delivery, the recurrence rate for a second pregnancy with breech presentation was nearly 10 percent, and that for a subsequent third pregnancy was 27 percent.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the area marked A in the given diagram?
questions.solution:
The area marked A represents the medial arcuate ligament. The thoracic sympathetic trunk passes posterior to it and becomes the lumbar sympathetic trunk.

questions.text: The concentration of a substance is 2 mg % in afferent arteriole and 0 mg% in the efferent arteriole of a patient. This substance is
questions.solution:
A concentration of 0 mg% is efferent arteriole indicates the substance is freely filtered.

Afferent arterioles → glomerulus (filtration) → efferent arterioles → peritubular capillaries (reabsorption+secretion).

Note: The question compares the concentration in afferent and efferent arterioles. Reabsorption and secretion happen between the tubular lumen of the nephron and the peritubular capillaries and not the efferent arteriole.

questions.text:
Match the following scientists with their discoveries:
1. John Snow      a. Germ theory of disease
2. Edward Jenner      b. Prevention of scurvy by citrus fruits
3. Louis Pasteur c. Association of cholera with polluted water
4. James Lind d. Smallpox vaccination
questions.solution:
The discoveries of the given scientists are as follows:

  • John Snow - association of cholera with polluted water
  • Edward Jenner - smallpox vaccination
  • Louis Pasteur - the germ theory of disease
  • James Lind - prevention of scurvy by intake of citrus fruits

Louis Pasteur was the first to advance the germ theory of disease, which stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. This theory was later expanded by Robert Koch, who put forth Koch's postulates.

Pasteur is also known for the following contributions:

  • Disproved the theory of spontaneous generation
  • Developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera
  • Pioneer of techniques of pasteurization and sterilization

questions.text: A patient has been posted for type 1 thyroplasty surgery. What does this procedure involve?
questions.solution:
Medialization of the vocal cord is done in type 1 thyroplasty. 

Type

Thyroplasty

Uses

Lateralization

III

To reduce pitch
