questions.text: Zero-order kinetics means____.

choices.text: Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time.
Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time.
Fraction of administered drug reaching the systemic circulation
Time required for reduction of drug concetnration to half of its initial value

questions.solution:
In zero-order kinetics, the rate of elimination remains constant, irrespective of the drug concentration. It is capacity-limited elimination and only a constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time.

Examples of drugs eliminated by zero-order kinetics include (WATT Power)

    • Warfarin
    • Alcohol, Aspirin
    • Tolbutamide
    • Theophylline 
    • Phenytoin

The constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit time occurs in first-order kinetics (Option B).

The fraction of administered drug reaching the systemic circulation is the bioavailability of the drug (Option C).

The time required for the reduction of drug concentration to half of its initial value is the half-life of the drug (Option D).

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: In your community medicine practicals, you are given an apparatus as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements regarding the apparatus is true?

choices.text: The indicator used is bromocresol purple
It is used to estimate free chlorine levels
It is used to estimate combined chlorine levels

questions.solution:
The image given is that of a Horrock's apparatus. The indicator used in Horrock's apparatus is starch iodide.

Horrock's apparatus contains 6 white cups (200 ml each), 1 black cup with a circular mark, 2 metal spoons with 2 grams of bleaching powder in each, 7 glass stirring rods, 1 special pipette and 2 droppers. It is not usful in measuring free and combined chlorine. It estimates the chlorine demand of water and is used to calculate the amount of bleaching powder used to disinfect the well.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: Hereditary phaeochromocytomas occurs in all except:
questions.solution:
Hereditary phaeochromocytomas occur in several tumour syndromes:

  • MEN 2
  • VHL
  • NF-1
  • Familial Paraganglioma Syndrome
  • Sturge-weber syndrome.

WAGR syndrome - Wilm’s tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary abnormalities, Retardation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female was brought to the hospital with complaints of recurrent episodes of acute onset breathlessness, palpitations, sweating and dizziness for the past 2 months. Physical examination and laboratory investigations were normal. Which of the following is the drug of choice in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of recurrent panic attacks suggest a diagnosis of panic disorder. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are the drug of choice in panic disorder.

Option B: Benzodiazepines are used in acute attacks of panic disorder.

Option C: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) and Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are second-line drugs for panic disorder.

Option D: Buspirone is a second-line drug used in generalized anxiety disorder.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: What is the dense zone of calcification seen at the metaphysis in scurvy?
questions.solution:
Dense zone of calcification at growing metaphysis seen in scurvy is known as Frankel's line.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: Which is a universal finding of asthma?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia is a universal finding during acute exacerbations. Most asthmatics have hypocapnia and respiratory alkalosis.

Other options:

Hypercarbia and Respiratory acidosis are very late features of asthma and point to severe obstruction and respiratory failure.

questions.text: A neonate with suspected birth asphyxia is intubated in the labor room after bag and mask ventilation did not yield successful results. All of the following parameters would indicate successful ventilation except ___________

choices.text: Zero reading of end-tidal CO2 measurement

questions.solution:
End-tidal CO2 should be present (EtCO2 should not be zero). This is an important sign of successful ventilation.

Successful ventilation is signified by the following:

  • Adequate chest rise
  • Symmetric breath sounds
  • Improved pink color
  • Heart rate > 100 beats/min
  • Spontaneous respirations
  • Presence of end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2 should not be zero)
  • Improved tone

questions.text: A male infant with a birth weight of 3.2 Kg is admitted to the phototherapy unit with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dl at 36 hours of life. Which of the following statements does not describe pathological jaundice?

choices.text: Jaundice appears within first 24 hours after birth
Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks
Jaundice associated with rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dl/24 hour
Jaundice seen in the mid-abdomen and soles

questions.solution:
Jaundice associated with a rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dL/24 hours suggests physiological jaundice.

Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

  • Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth
  • Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant
  • Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level
  • Total serum bilirubin levels above the expected normal range; jaundice seen in the mid-abdominal region (≈ 15 mg/dL) and soles (≈ 20 mg/dL)
  • Total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy
  • Total serum bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Periventricular calcifications and microcephaly in a baby with suspected congenital infection point toward cytomegalovirus (CMV). The best diagnostic method for CMV is PCR or viral culture on urine.

Since not all affected infants are viremic at birth, urine is a more reliable sample than blood. 

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), prematurity, and hepatosplenomegaly raise the suspicion of congenital infection. Hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, pneumonitis, petechiae, and meningoencephalitis are common to toxoplasmosis, rubella, CMV, herpes simplex virus (HSV), enteroviruses and syphilis. Hydrocephalus is seen in CMV, toxoplasmosis, HSV, and rubella.

The characteristic clinical features of various congenital infections are described in the table below:

Congenital infections Characteristic features
Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

Periventricular calcifications

Microcephaly
Toxoplasmosis

Chorioretinitis 

Diffuse intracranial calcifications 

Hydrocephalus 
Rubella

Sensorineural hearing loss

Salt-and-pepper retinopathy

Cataract

Glaucoma

Congenital defects like patent ductus arteriosus
Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

Vesicles

Microcephaly
Syphilis

Bone lesions (osteochondritis, periostitis)

Maculopapular rashes
Enterovirus (polio, rhinovirus, hepatitis A)

Myocarditis

Paralysis
Varicella zoster virus

Limb hypoplasia

Cicatricial skin lesions

Cortical atrophy
Zika virus

Subcortical calcifications

Microcephaly

Congenital contractures (arthrogryposis)
HIV

Thrush

Failure to thrive

Recurrent bacterial infections

Calcification of basal ganglia

The triad of congenital CMV infection includes intracranial calcifications (periventricular), microcephaly, and chorioretinitis.

Most CMV transmission occurs in the first trimester. The risk of transmission is high in the third trimester. 90% of the infected babies are asymptomatic and have lesser chances of having late sequelae.

In symptomatic individuals, ganciclovir can limit hearing loss and improve the developmental outcome, while there is no definitive management for congenital CMV infection.

The image below shows periventricular calcification in the head CT seen in CMV infection:

The image below shows a blueberry muffin rash, seen in TORCH complex infections and neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A 1.8 Kg neonate is born to a 24-year-old primigravida with no antenatal checkups.  While calculating the physical maturity of the neonate by the new Ballard scoring, which of the following criteria would you not take into account?
questions.solution:
Palmar surface is not a component of the physical criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score.

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Eye/ear
  4. Plantar crease (Not palmar surface)
  5. Breast
  6. Genitals

questions.text: A term, 4-month-old  infant,  is developing normally. By what age do you expect her to walk without support and use polysyllabic jargon?
questions.solution:
A 15-month-old child can walk without support and use polysyllabic jargon.

Walking: A child begins to cruise at 10 months, walk with support at 12 months, and walk without support at 15 months.

Jargon is seen around 15 months of age. It is a pre-linguistic vocalization in which the child babbles using strings of word-like sounds and produces words that do not make much sense to others.

questions.text: LBW is associated with increased risk of _____ in adult life.
questions.solution:
Low birth weight (LBW) (< 2.5kg) is associated with an increased risk of hypertension, stroke, and type 2 diabetes in adulthood.

The risk is exacerbated by low weight gain during the first 2 years of life.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true with respect to the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

choices.text: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge
Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants with immature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.solution:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period of time. 

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It is economic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. 

Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It requires frequent replacement.

Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a risk of aspiration.

World Breastfeeding Week is a global campaign celebrated 1-7 August every year. World Breastfeeding Week aims to highlight the benefits that breastfeeding can bring to both the health and welfare of babies, as well as for maternal health. The theme for the year 2022 is "Step Up for Breastfeeding: Educate and Support".

questions.text: Which epigenomic regulatory gene is mutated in most of the follicular lymphomas?
questions.solution:
MLL2 is an epigenomic regulatory gene that is mutated in most follicular lymphomas. It results in histone methylation.

Epigenetics refers to factors other than the sequence of DNA that regulate gene expression. These factors involved in epigenetics are:

  • Histone modifications
  • DNA methylation
  • Nucleosome positioning/ chromatin remodeling

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the right order with respect to Vitamin D metabolism:
1) Cholecalciferol
2) 1, 25 dihydroxycholecalciferol 
3) 25 hydroxycholecalciferol 
4) 7 dehydrocholesterol
questions.solution:
7-dehydrocholesterol in the skin is converted to Cholecalciferol (Vit D3) by the action of sunlight.

Cholecalciferol is inactive and is converted to an active metabolite 25-hydroxycholecalciferol in the liver.

It is further converted to another active metabolite 1,25-hydroxycholecalciferol in the kidneys (proximal convoluted tubules).

questions.text: What does the Paul-Bunnell test diagnose?
questions.solution:
Paul-Bunnell test is used to diagnose kissing disease.

Infectious mononucleosis (IM), or kissing disease, is caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Patients present with fever, pharyngitis, bilateral symmetrical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. A drug-induced rash may develop on using beta-lactam antibiotics. Large, atypical lymphocytes are seen in the peripheral blood of affected patients. 

Paul-Bunnell test is a heterophile agglutination test used for diagnosis of IM. It identifies the heterophile antibodies produced in IM that agglutinate sheep erythrocytes. In this test, inactivated serum of a patient is mixed with 1% suspension of sheep erythrocytes in serial dilutions. After incubation at 37°C for four hours the tubes are examined for agglutination. An agglutination titre of 100 or above is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. 

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: All of the following are true about insulinoma except ______.
questions.solution:
Patients of insulinoma eat frequently to avoid hypoglycemic symptoms. Hence, weight loss is not a feature of insulinoma.

Related Pearl: Whipple's Triad

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults?
questions.solution:
Malignant melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

questions.text: 'Putting profit ahead of health' as a cause of disease belongs to which theory of sociology of health?
questions.solution:
Putting profit ahead of health is termed as the cause of disease in the Marxist theory of sociology of health.

Elias' theory focused on the relationship between power, behavior, emotion, and knowledge over time.

Theory Marxist Parsonian Foucauldian
Description Emphasized causal role of economics in disease and the role of medical knowledge in sustaining class structure Emphasized role of medicine in maintaining social harmony Emphasized the role of ‘helping professions’ in inducing individuals to comply with social roles
Model of Society Conflictual and exploitative Harmonious and stable set of interlinked social roles and structures Net of power relations with no one dominant source
Cause of Disease Putting profit ahead of health Social strain caused by meeting the demands of social roles Diseases are labels used to sort and segregate the population to make it easier to control

Role of Medical Professional

To discipline and control the working class 

To provide individualized explanations of the disease

Rehabilitate individuals to carry out their social roles

To enforce compliance with the normal social roles and to ensure internalization of these norms.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a woman with bilateral and multicentric breast lumps?
questions.solution:
Bilaterality and multicentricity are most commonly associated with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).

LCIS occurs bilaterally in 50 - 70% of cases. Multicentricity is seen in 60 - 90% of patients with LCIS. 

Multicentricity refers to the occurrence of second breast cancer outside the breast quadrant of the primary cancer (or at least 4 cm away). Multifocality refers to the occurrence of a second cancer within the same breast quadrant as the primary cancer (or within 4 cm of it).

Related Pearl: Characteristics of in situ ductal (DCIS) and lobular (LCIS) carcinoma of the breast

 

LCIS

DCIS

Age (years)

44–47

54–58

Incidence

2%–5%

5%–10%

Clinical signs

Mostly incidental finding.

Usually asymptomatic but mass, pain, nipple discharge may also be seen.

Mammographic signs

None

Microcalcifications

Premenopausal

2/3

1/3

Incidence of synchronous invasive carcinoma

5%

2%–46%

Multicentricity

60%–90%

40%–80%

Bilaterality

50%–70%

10%–20%

Axillary metastasis

1%

1%–2%

Subsequent carcinomas:
  • Incidence

25%–35%

25%–70%
  • Laterality

Bilateral

Ipsilateral
  • Interval to diagnosis

15–20 y

5–10 y
  • Histologic type

Ductal

Ductal

questions.text: The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of _______.
questions.solution:
The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of inhibin secreted by Sertoli cells.

GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to secrete FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinizing hormone). FSH acts on Sertoli cells while LH triggers testosterone secretion by the Leydig cells. Sertoli cells secrete inhibin B which in turn inhibits FSH but stimulate LH secretion.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child from a rural slum area is brought to your OPD with deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with this deformity?
questions.solution:
Windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg) is seen in rickets. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but characteristically seen in rickets.

Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities of limbs
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur
  • Coxa vara

questions.text: The most common type of ventricular septal defect is ______.

choices.text: A and B have equal prevalence

questions.solution:
Membranous is the most common type of ventricular septal defect (VSD) to occur.

VSD is the most common congenital cardiac malformation.

Types of VSD include membranous (most common), muscular, inlet/atrioventricular canal defects, and supracristal defects.

Swiss Cheese septum: a special type of muscular VSD with defects in the mid-portion or apical region of the ventricular septum.

Restrictive VSD -A small VSD where the size of the lesion is usually <5 mm. It is associated with normal right ventricular pressure.

Non-restrictive VSD -A large VSD where the size of the lesion is usually >10 mm leading to equalization of pressures in the right and left ventricle.

questions.text: Three combat wounded soldiers with uncontrolled blood loss are brought to the base camp. Damage control resuscitation(DCR) is initiated for the soldiers. What is the correct ratio of PRBCs, FFP, and platelets that can be used for DCR?
questions.solution:
In DCR, the ratio of PRBC: fresh frozen plasma: platelets is 1:1:1. 

Administering blood products in the appropriate ratios in order to facilitate resuscitation from trauma and avert trauma-induced coagulopathy is termed damage control resuscitation(DCR).

The rationale behind 1:1:1 ratio- 

  • The red blood cell component will improve oxygen delivery to ischemic tissues.
  • Fresh frozen plasma improves clotting by providing clotting factors V and VIII and fibrinogen.
  • Platelet transfusion is required if the platelet count is below 50,000 / high power field, significant blood loss or prolonged resuscitation.

questions.text: When an ion on one side of a membrane cannot diffuse through the membrane, the distribution of other ions to which the membrane is permeable is affected in a predictable way. This is given by______
questions.solution:
Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a nondiffusible (protein) ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves (K+ and Cl-) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

  • Other options:
    • Nernst equation→ Calculation of equilibrium potential
    • Goldmann equation→ Calculation of diffusion potential when permeable to several different ions.
    • Henderson equation (Henderson – Hasselbach equation)→ Calculation of pH (acid-base balance).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is as shown below. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management. 

Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway).

Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of painless bleeding during defecation. On examination, a pinkish mass appears at the anal orifice when the patient is asked to strain. It reduces spontaneously when the patient relaxes. What will be the grade of this hemorrhoid?
questions.solution:
Prolapse with spontaneous reduction is suggestive of second-degree hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Grading of hemorrhoids

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of low mood for the past 2 weeks, reduced socialization, decreased appetite, and inability to sleep for the past 3 months. She also complains of frequent backache and headache, with early morning awakening. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood for the past 2 weeks along with reduced appetite, reduced interest in socialization, somatic symptoms, and disturbed sleep, points towards a diagnosis of depression (major depressive disorder). 

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. Atleast one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Other Options:

Option A: Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Option B: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months. It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. It is associated with poor insight. Patients believe that they have a serious disease that has not yet been detected and they can­not be persuaded otherwise. Their convictions persist despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the alleged disease over time, and reassurances from doctors.

Option C:  Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. It is distinguished from major depressive disorder by the fact that patients mention that they have always been depressed. There will never be an episode of mania/hypomania in this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about T cell dependent antigens?

choices.text: Their response doesn't show immunological memory
They activate only mature B cells

questions.solution:
T cell-dependent antigens activate only mature B cells.

Depending on their ability to induce the formation of antibodies, antigens are classified as T-cell dependent and T-cell independent antigens. 

T cell-dependent antigens (TD) T cell-independent antigens (TI)
Require helper T cell participation for the production of immune response Directly stimulate antibody production by B cells
Structurally complex Structurally simple
Activate only mature B cells monoclonally Activate both mature and immature B cells polyclonally
B cells undergo affinity maturation and class switch over B cells do not undergo affinity maturation and class switch over

All classes of antibodies are activated

 Antibody response is restricted to IgM and IgG3
Rapidly metabolized Slowly metabolized
Immunological memory present No immunological memory

questions.text:
The finding shown in the image below is seen as a side effect of which of the following drugs?
  1. Chloroquine
  2. Quinine
  3. Hydroxychloroquine
  4. Artesunate
  5. Lumefantrine
questions.solution:
The finding shown in the image is bulls-eye maculopathy, and chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine use are associated with this side effect.

Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, giving a bull's-eye appearance to the macula.

questions.text: A patient with chronic suppurative otitis media is posted for surgery. Preoperatively, the surgeon wants to assess the status of the ossicles so that he can be prepared for ossicular construction if required. Which of the following tests is useful here?
questions.solution:
The patch test is useful in assessing the status of the ossicles preoperatively so that the surgeon can be prepared for ossicular reconstruction if required. It is done in tubotympanic type of CSOM.

A thin paper-like cigarette foil is soaked in vaseline and cut into the size of perforation and is used to close the perforation. Pure tone audiometry is done before and after the closure of perforation. Results are as follows:

  • Improved hearing – intact ossicular chain
  • Decreased hearing – ossicular fixity or discontinuity
  • No improvement – technical fault or improper hearing.

Another test done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM is Bonsin's test. When the eardrum is painted with 1 in 20% solution of silver nitrate, the perforation stands out as a black spot against a white background.

Option A: Nine-step test is used to predict the ears at risk of middle ear barotrauma. 

Options B and D: The side-step test and Unterberger test are vestibular tests and are positive in perilymphatic fistula.

questions.text: Calculate the alveolar ventilation in a young man if the respiratory rate is 10/min and tidal volume is 600ml.
questions.solution:
Alveolar ventilation = RR X (VT –V D)

In the given case,

  • Respiratory rate (RR)= 10/min
  • Tidal volume (VT) = 600 mL
  • Dead space volume (VD) = 150 mL in a young man

Thus, Alveolar ventilation = 10 X (600-150) = 4500 mL/min = 4.5 L/min

questions.text: The following figure shows the transverse section of the uterus with an implanted zygote. Identify structure A.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the placenta.

Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called the decidua. It is of the following types:

  • Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum form the placenta. 
  • Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole. 
  • Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus.

The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes smooth, and is called the chorion laeve.

As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'.

Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.

questions.text: A woman, weighing 58 kg, has second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area.  Which of the following formulae would you use to calculate the amount of fluid to be given?

choices.text: Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 2 = volume in mL
Percentage of burns × weight (kg)/2 =  volume in mL
Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 4 = volume in mL
Weight + 1500 ml/m2×BSA burnt = volume in mL

questions.solution:
According to the latest ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) 10th edition 2018, resuscitation formula for second and third-degree thermal burns in the first 24 hours is given by the following equation:

Total percentage body surface area burned × weight (kg) × 2 = volume (mL).

Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours. This has been recommended to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula. 

Adequacy of fluid resuscitation is assessed by monitoring for a urine output of 0.5-1.0 mL/kg/hr.

However, in cases of electrical burns, the formula is: 

Total percentage body surface area burned× weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL).

Parkland and Modified Parkland formula:

  • Parkland's formula for resuscitation in the initial 24 hours is given by =  Total percentage body surface area × weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL).
  • Modified Parkland's formula provides more specific recommendations for the second 24 hours, advising colloid infusion of 5% albumin at the amount of 0.3-1.0/mL/kg/%BSA/hr. The management of the first 24 hours remains the same.

NOTE : Resuscitation formulas are not used in cases of superficial burns and in non-superficial burns with <20% TBSA

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: In a clinical trial to evaluate a drug, randomisation was done before starting the trial. What is the purpose behind this?

choices.text: The two groups will be similar in prognostic factors
The clinician has no control over the allocation of participants in each group
The clinician can predict in advance which treatment the subjects will receive
The sample may be referenced to a known population

questions.solution:
The main purpose behind randomisation is to eliminate selection bias.

In an RCT, participants are randomly assigned to a study group or a control group. It is done only after obtaining consent. It removes both known and unknown confounding factors.

The heart of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is randomisation. This allows comparability between the study and the control population.

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization

  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

questions.text: A tourist came to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. Which of the following strains of E. coli is most commonly implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient with watery diarrhea most likely has traveller’s diarrhea caused by Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC). 

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism that causes diarrhea in travelers. It produces the following toxins:

  • LT (heat-labile toxin) - acts by ↑cAMP
  • ST (heat-stable toxin) - two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
    • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑ cGMP in the intestine.
    • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.

Other options: 

Option A: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using E. coli adherent factor (EAF) and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) and causes effacement of microvilli. 

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.

Option D: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, which can be detected as a diagnostic test. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A woman delivered a child who died a few minutes after birth. The infant was found to have blue sclera and fractures of the right humerus, ulna, and femur at birth. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta type II.

The type II variant of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is uniformly fatal in utero or during the perinatal period. Type II OI is characterized by extraordinary bone fragility with multiple intrauterine fractures.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) is caused by deficiencies in the synthesis of type I collagen. It can be separated into four major clinical subtypes that vary widely in severity. The severity of the disease is based on the location of the mutation within the protein.

Individuals with type I OI have a normal life span, but experience childhood fractures that decrease in frequency following puberty.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with chest discomfort, associated with a squeezing sensation in the substernal area. She added that it was precipitated by physical activity and relieved on taking rest. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of stable angina in which the pain is usually crescendo-decrescendo in nature.

Characteristic features of pain in stable angina:

  • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort
  • Crescendo-decrescendo in nature
  • Typically lasts 2 to 5 min
  • Can radiate occasionally to neck, jaw, epigastrium, shoulders, left arm.

Angina is rarely localized below the umbilicus or above the mandible. Myocardial ischemic discomfort does not radiate to the trapezius muscles, that radiation pattern is more typical of pericarditis.

questions.text: What are the minimum and maximum values established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI?
questions.solution:
The minimum value established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI is 20 years and the maximum is 85 years.

These minimum and maximum values are used to calculate the dimension indices in HDI and are called goalposts.

Each dimension index is calculated using the formula:

Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value).

questions.text: A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test and states that her LMP was 8 weeks ago. However, she has a history of irregular cycles. Which of the following would be the most accurate way of dating the pregnancy?

choices.text: Abdominal circumference on transabdominal or transvaginal USG
Crown rump length on transabdominal or transvaginal USG

questions.solution: The most accurate way of dating the pregnancy is using the crown-rump length (CRL) on transabdominal or transvaginal USG. It has a variance of about 3 to 5 days.

questions.text: The following image shows the chest X-ray of a preterm neonate who was admitted to the NICU in view of severe respiratory distress.  What does this suggest?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture of respiratory distress in a premature neonate and the X-ray findings of diffuse ground-glass (reticulo-granular) opacities with a characteristic white-out appearance, hyaline membrane disease (HMD) is the most likely diagnosis.

HMD, also known as neonatal Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a relatively common condition resulting from insufficient production of surfactant that occurs in preterm neonates. Maternal diabetes, perinatal asphyxia, and multiple gestations are other known risk factors for the condition. Clinical features include tachypnea, chest retractions, expiratory grunting, and nasal flaring. The infant may or may not be cyanosed. 

X-ray features of HMD include:

  • Air bronchogram sign
  • Diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • Obliteration of cardiac and diaphragmatic contours giving rise to 'white-out' lung (indicates severe disease)

 

Chest radiograph (A) shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

questions.text: What is the denominator used in the formula for calculating the general fertility rate?

choices.text: Total number of women in the population
Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age group
Total number of married women in the age group 15 – 45

questions.solution:
The denominator used to calculate the general fertility rate is mid-year population of women in the reproductive age group.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A young boy came to visit his mother admitted to the antenatal ward for her delivery. You are the paediatrician on rounds in the adjacent post-natal cubical. His speech was very different from a normal child. Out of curiosity, you examine his oral cavity and the following finding is seen. What would be the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an abnormally short lingual frenulum called Ankyloglossia.

Ankyloglossia is also called “tongue-tie” due to an abnormally short lingual frenulum that can hinder tongue movement. It can interfere with speech or feeding. In such cases, surgical correction is indicated.

The image below shows tongue tie and the classic W-shaped appearance of the tongue on protrusion:

 

Fissured tongue (Option C) (scrotal tongue or lingua plicata) is a benign malformation in which numerous small furrows or deep grooves are present on the dorsal surface of the tongue. Food particles and debris may become trapped in the fissures, resulting in irritation, inflammation, and halitosis.

Macroglossia (Option D), or an abnormally large tongue, may be seen in disorders like Down's syndrome, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome, Hurler's syndrome, and cretinism.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treating with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Jaundice persisiting 3 weeks after birth is suggestive of pathological jaundice. Among the given options, Crigler Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which responds to phenobarbital therapy.  

Dubin Johnson (option C) and Rotor (option A) syndromes lead to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in the enzyme UDP UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

The differences between Crigler-Najjar type 1 and type 2 are described in the table below:

questions.text: Potassium binder used in cases of hyperkalemia is
questions.solution:
Patiromer is a non-absorbed, cation exchange polymer that contains a calcium-sorbitol
counterion.

It increases fecal potassium excretion through binding of potassium in the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.

Binding of potassium reduces the concentration of free potassium in the gastrointestinal lumen, resulting in a reduction of serum potassium levels.

Recent update: The FDA has approved Lokelma (sodium zirconium cyclosilicate), for the treatment of adults with hyperkalaemia in 2018. It is an insoluble, non-absorbed sodium zirconium silicate, formulated as a powder for oral suspension, that acts as a highly-selective potassium-removing agent.

questions.text: The stages of Cognitive Development was described by____

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
The liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors. It occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney. Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.

Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle. The Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as the Cahill cycle.

Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Sandfly. It is the vector for leishmaniasis.

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: A female newborn was delivered at 40 weeks of gestation by emergency C-section, following signs of severe fetal distress. Greenish amniotic fluid was noted. questions.solution:
The image shows patchy infiltrates and coarse streaking, which are characteristic findings in the chest X-ray image of infants with meconium aspiration syndrome.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A patient with a history of long-standing pulmonary tuberculosis undergoes a CT scan, and the image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The marked finding is known as the Monod sign, which is seen in aspergilloma. It refers to the presence of gas surrounding a fungal mass within a pulmonary cavity.

Aspergillomas (non-invasive pulmonary aspergillosis): Aspergillus fumigatus can cause mass-like fungus ball formation in structurally abnormal lungs (pre-existing cavities like in pulmonary tuberculosis). On Plain film and CT, an intracavitary mass surrounded by a crescent of air (Monod sign), is typically observed, as shown below.

Angioinvasive aspergillosis occurs primarily in immunocompromised patients. On HRCT, it is characterised by ground-glass opacity surrounding a pulmonary nodule or mass called a halo sign. This sign indicates a haemorrhage.

The below CT image depicts halo sign in invasive aspergillosis.

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is an immune reaction. The below image depicts gloved finger appearance of ABPA in the left upper lobe. It is a characteristic sign of bronchocele.

Other options:

Option A: Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially in the lungs and skin. The pulmonary disease resembles TB or histoplasmosis. There can be focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation.

Option B: A patient presenting with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration is most likely suffering from pneumonia. The CT image shows a sharply demarcated homogenous consolidation that crosses segmental boundaries and involves only a single lobe, suggestive of lobar pneumonia. 

The below CT scan image is highly suggestive of pneumonia in which consolidation with an air bronchogram can be seen.

Option D: Bronchiectasis is characterized by local and irreversible dilatation of bronchi. Radiographic findings are tramline appearance (seen on chest X-rays) and ring or curvilinear opacities on end-on appearance. CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of the bronchial lumen (cardinal sign) and signet-ring sign (internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery). 

CT image below shows thickened, dilated airways and signet-ring sign:

questions.text: What is the study and interpretation of post-mortem processes of human remains known as?
questions.solution:
Forensic taphonomy is the study and interpretation of postmortem processes of human remains i.e. the history of a body following death.


Option B: Thanatology is the scientific study of death among human beings in all aspects.
Option C: Criminology is social science approach to the study of crime as an individual and social phenomenon.
Option D: Anthropology is the study of all aspects of human beings.

questions.text: 35 year old male came to hospital with complaints of chest pain since 3 days which increases on lying down and improves on sitting and leaning forward. Patient also has breathlessness since 1 day. History of viral fever 15 days back which was managed conservatively. O/e: tachycardia +, no tachypnoea. Heart sounds are muffled, no murmurs are heard, bilateral vesicular breath sounds heard. Chest x-ray was done and is given below? What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Chest ray shows enlarged cardiac silhouette resembling water bottle heart characteristic of pericardial effusion. Usually patients give history of preceding viral infection. ECG shows global ST elevation with concavity. It is managed conservatively. Anti platelet agents and anticoagulants are contraindicated as they can cause hemopericardium. Occasionally patients develop tamponade and will require pericardiocentesis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. He had arrived from an international trip three days ago. A chest x-ray was done. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, chest pain and dyspnea after air travel most likely points to a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Westermark sign is seen in the given chest x-ray.

It is defined by a hyper-lucent area with decreased vascularity due to reduced blood supply to the involved part of the lung.

Even though characteristic signs are seen on chest x-ray, it is neither sensitive nor specific for pulmonary embolism. CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the investigation of choice in pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Name the staphylococcal infection that is not toxin mediated.
questions.solution:
Septicemia is not toxin-mediated but is the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream. Inflammatory mediators produced in response to bacterial products leads to various manifestations seen in sepsis.


Staphylococcus produces major toxins such as enterotoxin (food poisoning), toxic shock syndrome toxin (toxic shock syndrome), and exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin (staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome).
